content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												the "cover art" for this title is beautiful and i love me some old-school rpgs. however the art style from the store page is not carried over into the game. it is similar but you can tell a lot less of something (skill, time, or effort) went into it. shame really because i did not really find the art in game that engaging. to be clear i am not talking about the game world sprites; i am talking about the character avatars for conversations and battles. i honestly wish the devs had just used the sprites everywhere.that brings me to the inconsistency of the games aesthetic. it is not so jarring when the conversations have the non-pixel art, but in battles you have these fully rendered drawings (fully rendered does not mean beautiful, good quality, or high-res) that do not match the rest of the games art. even the background of the battle-scenes, those i saw, were the games pixel art. the pixel art in this game is good, but the non-pixel art is really quite unappealing. the entire battle scene could be improved so much if the dev had just used the pixel sprites they already had instead of the illustrations that are used.i also do not like that the battle scene does not use the character sprites as if they were on a battlefield like the original final fantasy games and chrono trigger. when i play 16-bit rpgs i want 16-bit art and my battles to happen in the game world rather than overlayed on top of it.i am not a connoiseur of good writing, but even i found the writing to be trite and unengaging. sure it is leaps and bounds better than legionwood 2, but it is still pretty terrible, even compared to some other classic rpgs with terrible writing.as you can see i did not play for very long, but that is because i found nothing to keep me playing longer and plenty to make me want to quit playing sooner. overall i cannot recommend this game.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												This is one of the most amazing games I have ever played. The storyline is enthralling, filled with original ideas and plenty of plot twists and turns. The games art is beautiful. Every time I battled against a new monster I simply marvelled at its beauty. The characters were incredible. They didn't feel like little pixels on the screen, they felt like they could be real people, as they were so incredibly well developed. My only qualm about the game is that towards the end, it felt rushed. Like the developers had all these wonderful ideas, but just shoved them in at the end.9/10 Well worth playing!

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Not bad, not great. Typical GBA style RPG if I had to throw it in a category. Kindof reminds me of Golden Sun or a FFIVish clone.I really do enjoy the steampunk styling, the optional battles, the battles themselves, full mouse function (one handed skill ++), augmentation of items, and the threat system. The card-like battles are a nice break from the all-too-common sprite battles (insert FF memories here). The threat system is overwhelmingly my favorite part of this game; all monsters focus their attacks on the character with the highest threat. Threat is dependent on damage dealt (think enmity/paladin if you've played FFXI), and pretty much eliminates the whole sh*t-my-healer-died headache.It's casual; you play it when you're watching investigative murder porn or whatever. I don't even know what the game music sounds like; I've played through it with iTunes on in the bkg, nothing's missed.  What I dislike:i. the menus are quite primitive. I had difficulty quickly comparing armor pieces upon pickup. ii. sprites for the monsters are overused. Haven't finished the game yet, but would've been interesting to see different models for different baddies. Why should you consider it? It's 15$. That's a movie; play it for 2 hours and you've been more cost efficient with your wallet than going to see a lame Thor sequel. If you miss older rpg games before the community was obsessed with graphics, you'll probably like this psuedo-throwback.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												Skyborn. I thought maybe this was about dragons. I had no idea this is about dragoons. So as the story goes. YOu start out as a tinkerer named claret. So you can not name any of the characters for your own. so this is not a options game. I believe this is a RPG Maker VX ace game that was enhanced with mouse support and some keyboard support. I know a script on getting the keys E, S, F, D to work on this. Oh lol im talking about scripts. Well you arrive in a town that has no map. So good luck. not that i dont like games with no maps but its very confusing. However on this title I was not so lost as I have a high IQ to figure out where I have been and where I wanted to go. I did like the mouse support as this made the way of walking very easy to point and click to use.  Now hmm the game feels like your going to do some grinding but there is very little as if you look for the little experience points in the game, then you dont really grind at all. Now I was concerned about what that has to do with the support jobs to earn. I think that the way you use the different weapons are great but the way you can only get a certain number of upgrades from the character. So if your looking for a way to get better upgrades. I believe there should be a picture of what your trying to achieve. It is like blind crafting and what are we crafting and is it better. I know this is a different perspective but crafting blindly to achieve a greater craft? You will just have to play to see what I mean. Five player support. Now that was a Party no doubt and the overall support of the last character was a 1:4 ratio as you are advancing with this character as to be like her. There are twist to her role and I support the team that came up with that. I wish there was more story to the Fey characters. If there is Skyborn 2 hopefully. I would try to support the character that is odd in the game and at least get a supply of weapons for her. I just feel characters need to support characters to a 50/50 percentage. That is how I feel I know that is not likely but character support would be nice. I do see that some of the characters really hate each other lol and so that was entertaining. Okay so I beat it once but I would replay this as to try to work on the areas I failed to see. There is a point of no return in the game and you better pay attention. The boss at the end is extremely difficult and will let you know if your worthy. So you get a free battle it seems till he decides at 30% he's had enough of you and WHAM whole party is retrying. OH the Army of the military Skyborn seems incomplete as I was not sure who the commander was or was that the point. Now the action of the sequence was intense. I did like the next character reference like something of Dragonwarrior series. I like to read the action. Can you tell? So you fight in a sequenced way of fighting and the options of availability are not in a constant order. So if you have a enemy that only gets affected by certain options of the party. So you need 3 characters at all times. If you have 1 or 2 in the other areas of the game. I believe you will see a cruel fate mostly.So with that said. I would recommend SKyborn to a player it is rare and seems like another of its kind shall embark soon....

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												I was in the mood for some steampunk game and noticed I had this (I'm assuming from some humble bundle). Thought I'd turn it on, play a few minutes and go meh. To my surprise I was enjoying it. Story is so far is... meh generic jrpg/rpg story line. However, it was the innovation with game mechanics for a jrpg that I was enjoying. Like a MMO it has a threat system. Balancing that threat bar to have your healer/squishies not be attacks and have your big swoll guy take all the damage. As well as mana regen in combat through either regular attack or when character turn ends (haven't figured out which one it was). As I keep playing though I do hope there are some more rpg elements like a class system or story choices... so on ward.. to keep playing and find out.    So far I would recommend it. For either a intro into the jrpg genre or just  innovation with the combat system. (This is atleast the first jrpg with these mechanics I've ran into... so their very well could be others that I've missed that have done the same thing.)

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Did a first play some time ago , didn't go that far, by lack of time mainly and characters didn't hook me up yet. Came back on it recently and I must say it's quite a gem of an "old-school" rpg. The story, without being groundbreaking is well written and the characters are really lively and relatable. No cliche of the "dark hero with a tortured past"  or the "happy go lucky kid who somehow gets stronger than veterans because ♥♥♥♥ logic he's the chosen one" here. It's a relief. When you kick a baddie's butt here, you feel gratified to teach him a lesson and that tells about how well the whole thing is written. About the gameplay itself though..... Well..... it's too easy. I'm playing on normal and plan to give a try with a second run on hard to check but damn, I didn't die once so far. The amount of augments and accessories make for a wide choice to modify your characters and also you can chose advanced classes which seem to propose pretty different strategies. I'm a bit disappointed enemies don't have better patterns and ai, especially bosses which I could basically faceroll against the floor in 2 minutes so far. Maybe it gets harder later but for now I'm at around 6 hours of real game (I left the game running while doing other stuff a lot) and no difficulty whatsoever. It doesn't disturb me that much because it's still fun and I play rpg more for the story than anything else. I wonder how some guys got lost in dungeons because the map design is pretty simple without being over-simplified either. You have room to get some extra-loot and xp which is always nice. Doesn't seem to have really hard to get secrets so far though. Time will tell maybe it comes later. The music also is pretty good. One of these games (like the Legionwood franchise) proving that YES, you can produce a good game with rpg maker. Without game-breaking bugs and actual fun. Which actually took time to polish. Incredible. Wow.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Difficulty leave: normalplaying casually not really puting forced thought and not really Saving and undoing mistakes just playing as if it were a fun game.Pros:The art is beaufitful it's really great and it seems to be rather clean then pixels.The Mechanics/ ui Everything runs smoothly, their interfaces for each menu look pretty and are very informative. I like the touches they did with the battles. Overal the Ui is being the Ui and doing it's job. telling me what I need to know without overwhelming me with boxes upon boxes. StoryThe story really interest me. has a bit of clice [parents left turns out they were rebels blah] but it's all clice when you look at all rpgs. The storys great you really can see how they play out in some scenes weapon craftingUnique and some what nice.  status effectsPlayers arn't restricted in status effects. all effects only lessen things and nothing takes away a players turn. blind something that would make you miss lowers your damage. there hasn't been a sleep spell nor has there been something that disables my player and makes me feel like that person is useless until there status effect is removed. any time I attack I feel that I'm doing something. Cons:Give a character a double attack.I craft a steel weapon [probably teir 2-3] and recieve a weapon in a dungeon i'm dealing 400 per hit twice. and if charged for a moment 1k possibly. This really hurts the fact that the main chracter is dealing all the damage. I get that 1's a healer 1's a tank and then you have your character. but for the early story thats 1 person dealing tons of damage 2-3 shotting all the monsters for no reason.... no reason at all. My tank tanks and my healers heals are kind of weak. and my 4th party memeber who is crit happy only deals 150 base damage. so I have to protect the double attacker because she is all my damage... :/ makes the game feel like I'm forced to deal all damage with her.Weapon crafting limitationSo I can't see what weapons I'm making or what armor I'm making and I understand something basic like a mage can't wear something heavy. and my tank shouldn't wear light things. but what does it all make? not knowing what desicion I'm making really hurts when I build a +2 damage for my damage dealer and get a new weapon in that dungeon moments later. or when I build something for my tank to attack and deal more damage to gain threat for the finishing blow and he gets a weapon. You can't craft weapons for other party memebers that I know of just yet. the first 4 you get you make weapons for the people who get items in the dungeon.... it makes crafting weapons worthless early on. and How was I to know?  I've just wasted resorces thats what I know.difficulty/ bossesbosses on normal difficulty arn't fun... You fight monsters 2-3 shot each of them, sometimes 1 shot. you fight the boss [which i've encountered 3] they hit all of your party memebers they 3 shot the tank and the 6 shot the person i'm desperatly keeping alive using heal all the potions I can throw on her because shes the ONLY ONE that can HURT THE BOSS. and a tech boss [2nd boss] and a female skyborn boss [3rd boss] share the ablity that gives them haste + all stats pretty much. :/ like really... Money issues. what exactly has real value...Your shops seem rather strange. you don't buy weapons you buy augments which can only be put on 1 weapon. ontop of that you don't need potions because you 2-3 shot everything. and you have a healer that uses 2-1% of mana to cast heal. and the mana used has no issues. no one has mana problems. :/ your tank uses 0 mana to taunt. your damage uses 22% to deal aoe damage which sets ablaze sometimes. and your crit happy person uses it to blind people. which just lowers damage and doesn't affect bosses... I have no clue what to spend the money on since Augments really seem like a 1 item use and you don't feel a value for them. Early game healer/ healing outside of comabt,healer in dungeon 1. It is little to no cost to heal and it has the problems of not really doing much of a heal inside of battle. The regen ablity is nice. and dehablity is nice but your taking a party memeber giving them the healler roll. so giving them damage doesn't really help your team. if your a healer. you need to use your action to heal. not deal damage. No grind factor.all encounters are plotted. meaning I can't go off and grind if i'm struggling with a boss. It's fine if the enemies are plotted but if they are. they need a respawn or their needs to be a way I can grind if I feel I'm unable to progress. If i'm struggling it means I've made a mistake with my resources but I have no way of destroying my weapon to craft armor. or to craft anything that could really help me out. heck I don't even know what teir my armor is when I get it because when I crafted new armor it was same teir as class 1 and I had no clue. their for MORE resorces wasted.Final analysis  I played the game and I'll still play the game for more research if my mind changes on this game and i'll rereview it but from first dungeons and bosses if it remains the same then It's going to stay this way. Art 5/5Game play 2/5Sound 4/5price 2/5 Story 4/5FInal verdict 6/10 Buy it if it's on sale for under 10 maybe 8 dollars but its not worth your 15 dollars... it really isn't Their are plenty of games that look nice sound nice but play better then what this has to offer in its early on game play.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Way too many mazes. Mazes within mazes. Just when you start to think you've covered most of an area and you can get on with the game, you find yourself in yet another maze. There's not much worth seeing or doing in these mazes, either -- a few mostly useless trinkets to "mine", very little loot, no lore or background story, just some sparkly nodes where you get a few XP or something. And doors and buttons and switches to really nail down that glorious maze experience. Combat system gets old quickly, too. Oh yeah, there are characters and a story here. Seemed pretty interesting. But somewhere in the middle of a maze within a maze within a maze, I stopped caring and remembered all the other games I have that involve actual playing and not wandering around aimlessly.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												Discalmer: I haven't finished the game. 2 hr 20 min played time.Combat:  The combat in this game is pretty simplistic.  You will pretty much be using the same two or three spells/abilities every round on any type of enemy.  Very little depth.  The threat system could have potential but it pretty much just makes it so you can have glass cannons and one tank.  It's very easy.Story:  I thought the story might be decent but after I left the first town I wasn't even sure why I was going to the places they were telling me to go.  Hey we made it to XXX, go though the coal mines to the next town!  Ok...why?  Good job, now proceed immediately though the volcano dungeon to the next town!  I quit in the volcano dungeon because it was just starting to feel like a grind.  Nothing was driving this story.Enviroments:  There's a good amount of detail on the map and it looks pretty well done for an RPG maker game.  The only downside is that there's not much you can interact with.  Also the enemies seem to be stock or something, most of the time I can't figure out why giant spiders, bandits, and skeleton men are all walking around in a room together.Graphics:  Look at the screenshots.  SNES level, no widescreen support.  AKA an RPG Maker game.I wouldn't say this game is bad but there's really nothing that made me excited or interested in playing it.  Do not recommend.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Couldn't stop playing. If you love JRPG's you will love it for sure.I like how simple the controls were, and the fact that there are no random encounters, which means your free to backtrack if you felt like you might have missed something. I do wish there was more customization and a general breakdown of what each stat means - sure some of them are fairly easy to guess such as magic defense. Doesn't mean a description isn't desired anymore though - many of these types of games have slight differences in how they treat certain stats.Agility for example might mean how fast I get my turn (Don't think so since they have a speed stat as well)It might mean how accurate I am, or how often I dodge (or both)anyway you get the idea - I don't like to guess.The characters and plot are the main driving factors here, while the gameplay is good, but nothing I felt was all that intuitive, though the main characters fighting style is a bit different than the norm.Overall I definitely recommend it , and had lots of fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												If you're an RPG fan I'd say pick this game up while it's on sale (at least 75% off) or in a bundle. I found the story premise to be interesting, the art to be overall nice looking, and the dungeons to be well designed. It's a fun game worth playing, but the asking price is entirely too high for what the game is. The following reasons are why I think that the game isn't worth what they are asking for it:1) The game is WAY too short for the pricetag. I did absolutely everything to do in game--all the sidequests as well as the optional bosses--and I clocked in at just under 15 hours of in-game time, which includes a few times when I left the game open while doing other things. I would expect at least 15 hours of base gameplay and 3~5 hours of extras for what amounts to about $15 USD.2) The plot was interesting, but extremely under developed; the ending also did not wrap things up as well as it could have. I would have liked to see a lot more time spent developing the world lore--both historical and present--in side quests and other optional events. I would also have liked to see more intra-character development in optional quests, events, and other places.3) The crafting system, while a good idea, was poorly designed. The UI was terrible (generic message window instead of a more in-depth interface that would let you know exactly what you were crafting) and the only things worth crafting were the +2 weapons. If this system had given the TLC it deserved, it could have added hours on to the fun bonus content.4)  The battle system is poorly balanced. I went through the entire game in hard mode. On the plus side, the beginning part of the game was actually hard enough so that I had to use items (I am a person who stockpiles items "for when I need them" and then never uses them), but by the time I got to my first class change I was tearing through the enemies like they were paper. The only battles that gave me trouble were the arena ones, the Venom Depth ones, Saehral, and the final boss (although the final boss was only troublesome because of bad timing). I believe I finished the game at around level 66 (Alda was 74ish because she was 10 levels ahead of everyone else), but only because beating Saehral levelled me up at least 15 levels.5) Bugs. There were some minor bugs regarding being able to walk on tiles that you shouldn't, but the big ones was that some of the item and augment effects didn't work as advertised.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												The Elder Scrolls V: SkyrimFrom Wikipedia, the free encyclopediaThe Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an action role-playing video game developed by Bethesda Game Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks. It is the fifth installment in The Elder Scrolls action role-playing video game series, following The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. Skyrim was released on November 11, 2011, for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. Three downloadable content (DLC) add-ons were released—Dawnguard, Hearthfire, and Dragonborn—which were repackaged into The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Legendary Edition, which released on June 4, 2013.Skyrim's main story revolves around the player character's efforts to defeat Alduin the World-Eater, a dragon who is prophesied to destroy the world. Set two hundred years after the events of Oblivion, the game takes place in the fictional province of Skyrim. Over the course of the game, the player completes quests and develops their character by improving their skills. Unlike previous The Elder Scrolls games, Skyrim does not require the player to select a character class at the beginning of the game, negating a problem the development team felt previous entries had by forcing the player into a rigid play-style too early into the game. Skyrim continues the open world tradition of its predecessors by allowing the player to travel anywhere in the game world at any time, and to ignore or postpone the main storyline indefinitely.The game was developed using the in-house Creation Engine, built specifically for the game. Skyrim is not a direct sequel to previous The Elder Scrolls games, and was considered a spiritual successor to Oblivion and 2008's Fallout 3. The team opted for a more unique and diverse game world than Oblivion's Cyrodiil, which game director and executive producer Todd Howard considered less interesting by comparison. The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim was released to critical acclaim, with reviewers particularly responding well to the refined character development and setting. The game shipped over seven million copies to retailers within the first week of its release, and sold over 20 million copies across all three platforms.GameplaySee also: Gameplay of The Elder Scrolls seriesThe Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an action role-playing game, playable from either a first- or third-person perspective. The player may freely roam over the land of Skyrim, which is an open world environment consisting of wilderness expanses, dungeons, cities, towns and villages.[3] The player may navigate the game world more quickly by riding horses, or by utilizing a fast-travel system that allows them to warp to previously-discovered locations.[4] The game's main quest can be completed or ignored at the player's preference after the first stage of the quest is finished. Non-player characters (NPCs) populate the world and can be interacted with in a number of ways; the player may engage them in conversation, marry an eligible NPC or kill them. As in previous Elder Scrolls games, killing certain NPCs can make some quests or items unobtainable. Some NPCs cannot be killed. If witnessed, crimes like murder and theft accrue the player bounty points in each of the world's nine districts. Should the player be stopped by a guard, they may wipe their bounty with gold or jail time, or may resist arrest which will trigger an aggressive pursuit. NPCs may allocate the player additional side-quests, and some side-quests have parameters adjusted based on nearby dungeons the player has yet to explore.[5][6] Some NPCs that are befriended or hired by the player may act as companions who will accompany the player and provide aid in combat.[7] The player may choose to join factions, which are organized groups of NPCs such as the Dark Brotherhood, a band of assassins or the player may choose to destroy them.[8] Each of the factions has an associated quest path to progress through. The cities and towns in the game world each have an economy, which the player can stimulate by completing jobs such as farming.[9]The player character engages in combat with monsters while exploring a dungeon. The player may dual-wield weapons and magic at once in order to be more effective against enemies.A perpetual objective for the player is to develop their character. At the beginning of the game, the player creates their character by selecting one of several races, including humans, elves and anthropomorphic (including cat and lizard-like) creatures, and then customizes their character's appearance.[10] Over the course of the game, the player improves their character's skills, which are numerical representations of their ability in certain areas. There are eighteen skills divided evenly between the three schools of combat, magic and stealth. When the player has trained skills enough to meet the required experience, their character levels up. Each time their character levels, the player may choose to select a skill-specific ability called a perk, or store perk points for later use. Unlike earlier entries in The Elder Scrolls series which used a character class system to determine which skills would contribute to the character's leveling, Skyrim allows the player to discover preferred skills as they play the game and rewards the player with more experience when a frequently-used skill is leveled.[5][11] A head-up display (HUD) appears when any of the player's three main attributes are being depleted. Attributes regenerate over time, although this process can be accelerated by using potions or regenerative spells. Health is depleted primarily when the player takes damage, and the loss of all health results in death. Magicka is depleted by the use of spells and by being struck by lightning-based attacks. Stamina determines the player's effectiveness in combat and is depleted by sprinting, power attacking, and being struck by frost-based attacks. The player's inventory can be accessed from the menu and items can be viewed in 3D, which may prove essential in solving puzzles found in dungeons.[12]

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												While it may be an RPGMaker Game with RPGMaker-ish textures and RPGMaker-ish Enemy Battle Portraits, I think it's hands-down the single best RPGMaker Game I've ever seen. Actually I think that's not doing it justice, I think it's actually one of the best Classic-Style RPGs I've seen. The level of detail that was put into this game with it's multitude of custom-drawn character artwork, each with multiple facial expressions. The battle system was fun and interesting, and not once did it feel "dull" or "repetitive" as these RPGMaker games tend to do sometimes.Even with the Vanilla RPGMaker Map Textures, this game knew exactly what it wanted to be and the Steampunk-ish world-setting was actually very beautiful to look at, I kinda had a huge nostalgia trip back to the days of SNES-Era Squaresoft Games such as Final Fantasy III while I was playing this. (That's what we called them back then. Nowadays, we say "Square Enix" and "Final Fantasy VI")I absolutely fell in love with the universe and it's characters. (Especially Chaska) And while the story never really graduates beyond your archtypical "Noble Rebels versus Evil Empire" which we've seen hundreds of times before, I feel as if that's not really much of a point against it when this game is so well made and so much fun to play.In short, this is not the "same ol' same ol' RPGMaker Game just like all the others." It really stands out from the very crowded scene of RPGMaker titles which all seem to blend together sometimes. And it's just plain really damn good. Should you buy it? Up to you honestly, but I most definitely recommend it.

Posted: February 23, 2014
												Without a doubt, one of the more enjoyable jrpg's, there's enough story driving you through each area for it to not feel nearly as repetitive as most of them. Even the music will make you raise an eyebrow in notice every now and then, the game feels like the devs actually cared about it. Downsides, it IS a rather short game, took about 5+ hrs to complete, but that's because you never actually have to grind. Also, although it is story driven, there are few extra areas to explore, gameplay is very linear. Despite this, still felt like a very enjoyable and complete package, pick it up if you want a good story to hold you through a day.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												This is a pretty good game, all things considering, it was made using the rpg maker I believe and it runs great. The art style is a great mix of old school rpg over world with very beautiful dialogue characters, not sure how to describe it but it is very well done. The combat is clean. It is turn based typical rpg combat with a cool new "Threat" mechanic that adds another depth to strategizing during combat. The combat is not animated save for the attacks but the enemy sprites look fantastic and you feel powerful using your different weapons and skills. The one gripe I have had with this game so far was the amount of time it took me to format my 360 controller to work with the game as the mouse and key board setting was not very comfortable, here is a tip when setting up controller pad, “C” is the “A (green)” button. And to access the configurations hit f1 but make sure you are not in any menus when you are tinkering with the layout. If you like old school rpgs you will love this game, also it is on humble bunde so you can get it for super cheap atm.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Overall, this a very good game. Although it's got a few problems, these can easily be overlooked.The Good________Story: The plot is engaging, with a lot of neat moments where you feel emotionally compelled to keep playing. If you're playing an RPG, you NEED a good story to compel play. At the beginning you're forced to betray/trick someone to save your family. Who isn't willing to do everything they can for their family?BGM: The music is very atmospheric, usually fitting situation well and sound very much like music from games on the PS2 or XBOX. The music is in stereo as well, but this is less useful than stereo sound effects.Graphics: The visuals are reminiscent of the 16-bit era of console gaming in terms of color and the sprite drawing methods common on the NES/SNES, Genisis, and PSX. More than anything else I'm reminded of the original Dragon Warrior (Dragon Quest) 1-3 and Breath of Fire 1 and 2 games in regards to gameplay, with a Town overmap, a menu overmap, dungeon overmap, and world overmap, along with the turn based combat system. Also, when going full screen on my monitor the game doesn't look bad, but doesn't have 1080p support running at 640x480, so probably won't work well with or look good on TVs.The Bad_______Sound: The sound effects are very subpar by todays standards, but equal to if not better than those of the 16-bit and 32-bit console era. The sound effects do not seem to be in stereo.Sound/Visual Timing: Often sound effects, i.e. attacks in combat, will occur just before the visual identifier does. This tends to throw the combat immersion right out the window for me, but it's not overly horrible, and certainly doesn't break the game.The Ugly_______Controls: X-input controllers, that is to say anything resembling the Xbox 360 controller, have wonky button command registers, with Menu/Cancel being assigned to B and Interact/Accept being assinged to X, and Previous Page/Next Page being assigned to Back/Start respectively. Worse, still, there is no way to reassign them in game.The controls for D-input controllers, resembling Playstation 2 or 3 controllers, is much better with Menu/Cancel being assigned to X and Interact/Accept being assigned to O, and Previous Page/Next Page assigned to L2/R2 respectively. The Logitech F series controllers 310, 510, and 710, are able to switch between these input types, so I recommend using D-input with them. I've tested PS3, Wireless Xbox 360 for Windows, and Logitech F510 controllers with this game.Mouse and keyboard are simple enough with the avatar attempting to take the shortest route to where you click on the overmaps or moving in the cardinals with the arrow keys, and clicking on commands and enemies in combat or selecting them with left/right arrow keys and pressing enter.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												Skyborn is a rather unique RPG game in the sense that it plays somewhat like an old Dragon Quest game. It has a first-person battle system, with vastly different skills for each character. It also features XP spots, shiny lights that give you a good experience boost. There are several levels of difficulty, which can be changed if you want to increase or decrease the challenge. There are quite a few achievements, most of which are practically unmissable if you explore everything and talk to everyone. There aren't many side quests, but a few of them do give achievements and good rewards. There's even an arena/colisseum to test your mettle (which I'd advise taking on as soon as you get your final party member). The story isn't anything new, but it is interesting and fun nonetheless. The banter between the characters is humorous and entertaining, especially Claret and Sullivan. Skyborn is ultimately an unfortunately somewhat short RPG but fun nonetheless. You will be glad you played it but will be left wanting more. So in the mean time, play Echoes of Aetheria afterwards.Length: 10-15 hours, depending on play stylePros:A good story, some funny parts, mostly light-hearted but with some dark bits here and thereFun gameplay, some challenging fights, battle arenaNice custom tilesets and graphicsGreat character art that conveys emotions and goes well with the dialogueSnarky dialogue and humor, some funny easter eggs and references here and thereCons:Short game. Ended too soon but felt complete for the most partRPG Maker game. So with that, it has some of the same annoyances that most RPG Maker games have: No resolution options, stretched fullscreen, no D-pad support for gamepads, etc.tl;dr: Definitely get it on sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												Tl;DR: Bugs, awful storyline that could've been written by a twelve year old, same old pixel-rpg elements, brings nothing worthwhile to the table. 3/10For the however-long I played this game, I never want to play it again. I was lucky enough to get it free in a giveaway, but if you are considering paying for this, I beg you to consider your money put elsewhere.The story, and characters, are quite frankly, abyssmal. You play Claret Spencer, your typical 18 (16? I don't know she was never given an age.) year old-raging-on-hormones-because-all-girls-do-that shop mechanic. The characters act so suprised about things that should be understood so easily. The characters had to re-explain to Claret over and over certain aspects of the universe, like skyborns and magic. I've been here for ten minutes and I understand everything in this games history better than the main character that has spent her life here.As for bugs, straight off the first weird conversation scene thing, you walk out of your shop and can just ♥♥♥♥ing walk through guard rails and stairs to stand in puddles or walls. The stairs are also really gimicky, sometimes you get thrown off of them into walls and stuff, but don't worry, just phase your way back into reality by walking in said wall till you reach the actual path again.This game brings nothing new that is worthwhile to the table. It has a "threat" system, where enemies attack whoever of your party attacks them more, which at first seems like a cool idea, till you get a mage and relize you can constantly heal the character they're attacking and never worry about said mage taking damage, pretty much impossible to die, making combat boring pretty fast.WARNING: SPOILERS -- What I really wanted from this game was choice, I wanted to join the super-cool skyborn soldiers but instead the game makes them out to be complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who try to kill you, a random human they've never seen before, whenever they meet you. At one point you're told to follow the rebels back to their hideout and report back to a skyborn to get your brother out of prison. I was totally ready to do that, but then the "Red Spectre" tells you what "horrible" people the skyborn are, torturing humans to see if they can use magic. I didn't care, sounds like an effective way to see who can use magic to me! But when the time comes you have no choice and you're character imediately without your consent is like "HOW HORABLE IL HALP!!!!XOXOXO".I could keep going, there are TONS of plot holes in this game, your brother apparently sells your shop, and you along with it, to an actually nice rich guy who your character hates for no reason, simply because your brother wants to go out and see the world...or something. Oh and your character is mad at the skyborn because they arrested your friend/boyfriend/employee for being a half-breed when he is in fact a half-breed and the skyborn were totally right. But whatever, you're automatically good no matter what you do because you're the hero, right!?!?!Anyway, this game just infuriated me to no end, I actually quit when it MADE me sign up for the rebels. 3/10 would not play again.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												After going through the game twice I decided I'd review it. Let's start with the good:Pros:Probably the best overall of the RPG Maker games.The protagonists are generally likeable and believable characters.The antagonists do a good job of making you hate and want to beat them.The game mechanics have a reasonable amount of depth and options that are introduced gradually throughout the course of the game which prevents information overload.With one exception, the game plays fair and enemies generally have access to the same options and resources as the player.Cons:Very short, especially for an RPG.Very easy, even on Hard difficulty. Even the optional superboss.The final boss has an unavoidable death combo and the fight lasts long enough he usually gets at least one chance to use it on you at which point everyone dies. He is otherwise entirely trivial.Mostly linear. There aren't many side quests overall and most of them are along the lines of complete an additional objective in the area you were going anyways instead of directing you somewhere else. It's also rare there is more than one place you could go and get something done at any given time.Once you get past the first few levels you no longer gain skills by leveling up, only by reaching certain points in the game.What I'd like to have seen:At least twice as long.Buff the difficulty considerably (leave Easy easy for those not looking for a hard game).Buff all the final boss' attacks except for the unavoidable death combo, then either make sure you always have time to react or make it not always kill everyone instantly. That way he provides a hard but legitimate challenge.More side quests and side areas.Instead of class changing instantly granting all the skills, make it give one now and the rest with level requirements.Massively buff the super boss. She's honestly a joke, her best attack does 2k or 3k on all at full power. Anyone complaining she's hard didn't go in prepared at all and is taking much more damage than that.

												Many of the positive reviews laud it as being one of the best RPGMaker games out there. The others it is compared to must be appalling, rather than merely bad.There's good things about the game- the aesthetics and music are fine for example. The story is simple and predictable, and is hinged on several strokes of unlikely luck. The battle system is poorly tuned and unbalanced, with the rare occasions you have something challenging even if underlevelled then relying on rolling back to an old save or more likely repeating the fight hoping for the status effects to stick or be dodged by your party.If you want a quick jrpg style game and can get it for a tiny amount of money then as other reviews state there are worse choices.

												I was shaken after putting a few hours into this game! The music, attention to meaningful details regarding characters and plot  have given me a greater respect for RPG Maker products. I believe in supporting small developers and indie so if you see this game and want to similar experiences to Chrono Trigger or Final Fantasy you will not be disappointed. Posted: June 7, 2014
												It's ok, it plays well, the dialague is well written, the dungeons are well thought out and not too hard to figure out, there are no random encounters so you can skip a few if you like. the story is allright, it's not shakespeare but it was interesting enough for me to play though the whole thing on a lazy day. the characters are very likeble so it is kind of sad how they are relegated to about one or maybe two character moments each.it can take anywhere from 4-10 hours to fully complete depending on sidequests and optional bosses. so if you want to throw some money and get something to occupy yourself for a day, it's worth it

Posted: June 11, 2014
												Good RPGMaker Game that reminds you of the "Golden Days" of RPGs during the SNES Era.The Battle System is what amazed me about this game. A Threat System, in a Turn-based RPG? Awesome! The Action List reminded me of games like Final Fantasy X and Final Fantasy Tactics, while the Threat System clearly takes ideas out of MMORPGs.The Crafting system has its flaws; you can't see WHAT you're about to make until you've already made it, but thankfully you can save anywhere so you can save before you use your materials. A couple hours into the game and I'm already making "Tier 3" gear, so something tells me the game isn't hugely long. But then it doesn't have to be; I've played a lot of Sub-5 hour games and enjoyed them for what they were.The story seems well-written thusfar, it is basically a Final Fantasy in a Steampunk setting. Pretty standard fare, though this isn't a bad thing for those looking for some nostalgia. The characters seem fairly well-done, each with their strengths and weaknesses (though the Claret seems a touch overpowered). The Magic and Energy Systems are well-implemented and make sense, and the Class Changes were an interesting addition as well.Overall: 8.5Short, enjoyable nostalgia trip for those of you who remember the SNES Era Final Fantasy/Lufia-type games fondly.

Posted: May 25, 2014
												This is an awesome game! I generally have two requirements for a game: Good story, and visually pleasing. This is both. And on top of that, it has great music!I breezed through it in about 8 hours, but I'm also severely directionally challenged and tend to wander around the same areas several times, just in case I missed something. This is a good game for wandering, especially in some of the later levels because it's just darn pretty! If you're like me and you want to do ALL THE QUESTS and find ALL THE THINGS, you can probably get another few hours out of it. Aditionally, when they tell you that you're about to go past the point of no return, they really mean it! If you have unfinished quests, or if you just want to meander through some areas again, make sure you do it before taking on that mission.Overall, it's a gorgeous game, great music, and a wonderful story line. Definitely worth the money.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												All in all, you can play through it in about 6-7 hours, so not a long game. Nice story, moderately acceptable (if clicéd) characters. Item variety seems OK. Graphics-wise, I wish the ingame character-drawings got nearly the same attention as the one on the boxart. They are jarringly different. It has its own set of bugs (the most annoying is hiding  the enemy life bar about a second after it changes), but it is playable. There is also crafting that can get you some pretty nifty items. All-in-all, nice, but short indie RPG. Not worth the 13€, but for $1 bundle, it was A-OK.

Posted: May 6, 2014
												Solid RPG in the styles of the early snes rpgs.Good story and a good pace throughout.Visuals are good with some things being slightly off due to this being made on rpgmaker, the theme is fantastic but due to the retrictive tile based system you end up with all land being made of squares. Posted: May 8, 2014
												First off, ignore all the complaining about RPG maker.  If an RPG has a good plot in an interesting setting with unique characters and a good combat system, who cares how it was made?  Luckily, Skyborn has all this and more.  It starts off fairly easy but the combat system has enough depth to really give you a challenge after the first few areas.  I played on medium difficulty and I found the battles challenging and fun.  There are also plenty of optional battles in the late game that will challenge you, but they're not needed to beat the game. The story is the best part of Skyborn.  There's a unique setting combined with memorable characters.  The game is a nice length as well.  It's probably 11 to 15 hours total.  I did all 4 sidequests along with the arena and the Venom Depths which are optional, along with maybe 45 minutes of afking for dinner, beer, and bathroom breaks.  As far as the details of the game go, I enjoyed the level design.  Graphics are SNES level, but I'm playing for the plot and there were some moments where certain levels looked quite pleasing and so I'd say the graphics are fine for the genre.  The plot and setting were great.  This isn't a generic steampunk cliché universe.  There's no annoying puzzles and all but one time it was clear where to go next. The crafting and augmenting system is deep enough to cause you to put some real thought into what to upgrade and it's fairly open.  You can skip crafting if you like, but it's fun to forge very powerful weapons for your favorite character.  The music was ok, not fantastic.  Sound effects were solid.  In the first 2 to 3 hours of the game, the enemies can seem a little repetitive and it's a bit too easy (on medium) but that changes.  There's also no real "grinding" levels.  Enemies do not respawn so it's to your advantage to fight every enemy, but you don't just have to sit around leveling up.  Bosses are challenging and feel epic.  Overall, I'd give the game an 8/10 for being an enjoyable, well made RPG.  It's a bit expensive at the current 15$ price tag, but if you can pick up this game on a sale, it's worth it.

Posted: April 27, 2014
												I got Skyborn in a bundle a while back and played it last week, and it's a surprisingly decent game - there's almost no grinding, the characters are fairly diverse (though there's a slight flaw with one of them due to how his MP mechanic works in the late game), it's somewhat well written (though the plot is fairly generic) and it doesn't overstay it's welcome (since it's only 8hrs long, though I imagine you could get another one or two with the bonus dungeon I didn't touch). It may not be worth £12, but I could see it being worth buying at 66% or 75% off if you fancy a decent JRPG or RPGMaker game.

Posted: April 26, 2014
												Skyborn had a fun cast of playable characters and a combat system that's simple yet enjoyable. It's sort of short but a pleasurable experience all around. If you want something that won't take a lot of time, I'd recommend this game.

												For a fairly short game, the story and gameplay are nice.  Good throwback to the old SNES days.  Fights can either be fairly easy, or tough as nails even on an easy setting.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												A pretty standard RPG mechanic.  However, it is an excellent story, with a good soundtrack and artwork.  It's definately a game to play for an RPG fan.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												Final Fantasy VI meets Firefly.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Skyborn is . . . competent, I guess I'd say. Not amazing, but not bad. Its strongest points are the setting, story, and characters. Admittedly, there are a lot of bog standard tropes across the board, but they're pretty well-executed. The world is interesting, and I found myself wanting to know more about it. The characters are well-written and more fun than I expected. The story could have benefited from more development and better pacing, but still, it was engaging enough to keep me playing to the end (seven hours or so).That's more than I can say for the combat, however. My biggest issue with the game is how boring the combat became. I'm not an RPG veteran by any stretch, and I paid almost no attention to Skyborn's mechanics, yet I was still able to snooze through all but one fight. Sooner rather than later, Claret got some mega-OP skills that obliterated anything that tried to get in her way, which completely trivialized most of the enemies and turned encounters into tedious detours. Also, the combat screen uses default RPG Maker enemy sprites, which often look weirdly out of place amongst the otherwise consistent anime aesthetics.Final verdict: yes, it's worth playing, but wait for a sale.

Posted: July 14, 2014
												Skyborn is a beautifully crafted world with art work that reminsces from the SNES era. The graphics and art are better than that, but the RPG style is exactly the same.Anyone who played those games, I mean really played them love them. You'll love Skyborn too. It mostly does everything those games did.However Skyborn is a small game. I would call this a one and done deal. You play it once, feel fully satisfied, and never touch it again. That's ok. Not every game has to be a game you play a bunch of times. Not every book is a book you read multiple times. Not every movie is a movie you watch more than once. Enjoy the game for what it is because it is a lot of fun. I had a great time with it.Classic JRPG feel with better graphics. If that's what you're looking for, you'll get it in this pint sized adventure. If you spend 4 hours on this game, you rushed through it and shame on you. If you spend 6 or more, you spent time and explored.

Posted: March 26, 2014
												A nice little RPG for the price. The game really ramps up in difficulty after about 5 hours in playing on the hardest difficulty. For a while I had actually forgot I was playing on the hardest difficulty. At this point there were several fights that had me worried I might actually have to restart from my save. After getting the current tier armor and weapons upgraded and augmented I still have one or two party members go down each fight. Steel Slimes hit like a truck >.> Boss fights up to this point have been fairly simple with them dying in a round or two. I have yet to fight a boss since the difficulty curve has been upped. If the regular monster battles are any indicator it is going to be very difficult. There is also a little bit of humor in the game that I find quite enjoyable. Storytelling is pretty good as well.Overall I am quite pleased with this game.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												I know people give RPG maker games a lot of flack but just because something is made with a game making engine doesnt mean it has to be terrible. Both Unity and the Unreal Engine could be considered game making tools, albeit on the more high end. I think the reason that RPG Maker gets such a rough rep is that its so accessible anyone can use it and therefor you end up with more♥♥♥♥♥♥than gold. Happily Skyborn is pure gold and while the actual tile sets are mostly of the stock type that come with the set, the character portraits are amazingly detailed and expresive and the author is himself a professional musician so the soundtrack is incredible. Set in a steampunk world where the humans are oppressed by a group of winged beings known as the Skyborn, the reluctant heroine Claret is drawn into a rebellion, first merely to save her brother but then out of altruism as she sees just how badly the Skyborn treat the lower classes. It has a great cast of likeable characters and while, as with many RPG's the combat can be a bit grindy, it has enough clever mechanics to keep you going til the end. 20 hours game for $14.99 is pretty good value. Get it.

Posted: July 23, 2015
												Growing up, the first RPG I ever played was Dragon Warrior on the NES, then it was Zelda, then between the NES and SNES I played the Final Fantasies, etc.  JRPGs were a genre I loved, even if I didn't really know the genre name back then.  I haven't played a JRPG-ish type of game since Albert Odyssey on the Sega Saturn back in the mid 90's honestly, so when I saw Skyborn pop up, I was intrigued.  I was hopeful that Skyborn would capture that spirit and feel that made me fall in love with the genre (but not rely on nostalgia).  My expectations were met and exceeded.  This is a fantastic JRPG game that has all the elements that make the genre great.  The story is fantastic, the battle system is tight, the graphics are clear and crisp and the musical score is extremely well done.  Another thing I enjoy here are that there are elements of random turn-based battles, but it's not random at all.  Enemies walk on paths that you can somewhat predict.  If you engage an enemy, you battle.  If you avoid the enemy, you don't.  There are certain narrow walkways where it would be hard to avoid an enemy, but honestly, you could probably play the entire game with only accidentally engaging a few enemies.  Or, you can choose to engage all enemies.  I love this option, because you still get plenty of fighting time, but you have a say in exactly when you'll be battling. The end result is a 8 hour (if you play just to win) to probably 15 hour (if you do all the quests and explore everywhere) JRPG that anyone will love who is a fan of the genre.

Posted: March 15, 2014
												I wasn't expecting much when I started up Skyborn, but was pleasantly surprised almost immediately. It has a very well-developed and likable cast of characters. The combat and game mechanics are just deep enough to make you plan things out, but intuitive enough that you'll know what you're doing right away. I especially enjoyed the Augment system, which allows you to add various effects to your gear and dramatically improve their usefulness. The music is also very well done, enough that I would even be willing to pick up a soundtrack. The story isn't anything spectacular, but it's simple and engaging enough to keep you interested for the entire length of the game (which was about 11 hours, including all of the sidequests). The adjustable difficulty level is also extremely useful, because with a bit of planning and sidequesting, you can become pretty much unstoppable and render most end-game foes meaningless.All in all, I give this an 8/10, and definitely recommend it for anyone looking for a good retro-style RPG.

Posted: June 11, 2014
												Good RPGMaker Game that reminds you of the "Golden Days" of RPGs during the SNES Era.The Battle System is what amazed me about this game. A Threat System, in a Turn-based RPG? Awesome! The Action List reminded me of games like Final Fantasy X and Final Fantasy Tactics, while the Threat System clearly takes ideas out of MMORPGs.The Crafting system has its flaws; you can't see WHAT you're about to make until you've already made it, but thankfully you can save anywhere so you can save before you use your materials. A couple hours into the game and I'm already making "Tier 3" gear, so something tells me the game isn't hugely long. But then it doesn't have to be; I've played a lot of Sub-5 hour games and enjoyed them for what they were.The story seems well-written thusfar, it is basically a Final Fantasy in a Steampunk setting. Pretty standard fare, though this isn't a bad thing for those looking for some nostalgia. The characters seem fairly well-done, each with their strengths and weaknesses (though the Claret seems a touch overpowered). The Magic and Energy Systems are well-implemented and make sense, and the Class Changes were an interesting addition as well.Overall: 8.5Short, enjoyable nostalgia trip for those of you who remember the SNES Era Final Fantasy/Lufia-type games fondly.

Posted: May 8, 2014
												First off, ignore all the complaining about RPG maker.  If an RPG has a good plot in an interesting setting with unique characters and a good combat system, who cares how it was made?  Luckily, Skyborn has all this and more.  It starts off fairly easy but the combat system has enough depth to really give you a challenge after the first few areas.  I played on medium difficulty and I found the battles challenging and fun.  There are also plenty of optional battles in the late game that will challenge you, but they're not needed to beat the game. The story is the best part of Skyborn.  There's a unique setting combined with memorable characters.  The game is a nice length as well.  It's probably 11 to 15 hours total.  I did all 4 sidequests along with the arena and the Venom Depths which are optional, along with maybe 45 minutes of afking for dinner, beer, and bathroom breaks.  As far as the details of the game go, I enjoyed the level design.  Graphics are SNES level, but I'm playing for the plot and there were some moments where certain levels looked quite pleasing and so I'd say the graphics are fine for the genre.  The plot and setting were great.  This isn't a generic steampunk cliché universe.  There's no annoying puzzles and all but one time it was clear where to go next. The crafting and augmenting system is deep enough to cause you to put some real thought into what to upgrade and it's fairly open.  You can skip crafting if you like, but it's fun to forge very powerful weapons for your favorite character.  The music was ok, not fantastic.  Sound effects were solid.  In the first 2 to 3 hours of the game, the enemies can seem a little repetitive and it's a bit too easy (on medium) but that changes.  There's also no real "grinding" levels.  Enemies do not respawn so it's to your advantage to fight every enemy, but you don't just have to sit around leveling up.  Bosses are challenging and feel epic.  Overall, I'd give the game an 8/10 for being an enjoyable, well made RPG.  It's a bit expensive at the current 15$ price tag, but if you can pick up this game on a sale, it's worth it.

												LOVED This game. It took me about 8 hours to clear (I played in offline mode on my laptop for half of it). The combat is balanced and the characters are interesting and all useful in their own way. All characters are customizable from picking which skills they learn, to choosing equipment, to finally choosing which item/buff to apply to each piece of equipment. Building up my characters was the funnest part. The combat is interesting. It has a threat system where enemies focus on the party members doing the flashiest moves. Exploring the game world is vastly rewarding and encouraged. Not only do you find great gear, but you can find experience points by exploring. The game also has additional side content that I didnt complete in my 8 hour playthrough. This includes, a fighting arena, a side dungeon to explore, and finding a deck of cards that has been scattered across the land. My only complaint is that the weapon/armor crafting system in this game seems tacked on and forgettable. The items you can craft are limited and you usually have them by the time you can craft them anyway. Having said that, this is a game that no RPG fan should miss out on. 9.5/10

Posted: February 28, 2014
												An endlessly charming and simple Japanese-style RPG that brings to mind Square's SNES efforts, as well as lesser-known Genesis and Turbografx adventures (Lunar and Cosmic Fantasy come immediately to mind).  Easy to grasp mechanics and an interesting story punctuated with excellent writing and the first truly likeable cast I've come across in quite some time.  It speaks volumes that I enjoyed this humble little title more than recent multi-million efforts from big name developers.  It's quite succinct at only 7-10 hours long, but there's also little pointless backtracking and padding to slog through.Absolutely recommended to gamers that look back fondly on the golden age of console RPGs.Note: Disregard people dismissing Skyborn because of the engine it was built with.  RPG Maker is fully capable of producing unique and captivating games in the right hands, as evidenced by Yume Nikki, To the Moon and the subject of this review.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												For a casual RPG player like myself, Skyborn was a wonderful little game with a poignant story, fun gameplay, and quick pace.  There was never a need for tedious grinding--in fact, you could avoid most battles if you wanted to, but I don't know how that would affect your leveling.  Shops were placed conveniently between stretches of dungeon to buy (or make) better weapons and armor.  You could also buy supplies, although the plentiful item chests usually provided enough for me.  Some areas (Nordenwald Forest *cough*) were rather lengthy with extended puzzles involving painful walking from one end of the map to the other.  Aside from the particularly grueling dungeon and the utter lack of promised side quests, Skyborn proved to be a short but delightful game.  I'll certainly be replaying it in the future to try different class combinations and fighting styles.

If you're looking for any kind of gameplay balance, do speed runs. Posted: February 25, 2014
												I couldn't remove a selection and I couldn't make an intermediate selection so I went with yes.  I enjoyed playing the game for the most part.  The story may use a tried and true plot device, but it does contain a few twists that I, at least, didn't see coming.  The world is fairly small, but most of the areas are very diversified so it doesn't feel that way.  Also the smithing is a nice touch, though I would have liked to make higher quality armor as well. My problem with the game was the combat balance.  For one I almost immediately turned the game up to hard.  This is something I almost never do as I generally like to keep combat just difficult enough that I keep interested without becoming a hassle.  On Normal there was absolutely no challenge.  For most random encounters that didn't change much on Hard.  Boss battles, came in two varities: 'What just wiped me in 2 seconds' or 'what did I just roll over.'  There are certain skills in the game (For you and your enemies) that are just ridiculously strong.  But if you don't use them, then battles just drag on because at least with how I was building characters (trying to emphasize +Str as much as I could!) only 1-2 of my characters ever did appreciable amounts of damage.  Also the character classes are very specialized. Only certain people dealt damage, and at times it really felt the only reason "threat" existed was to give the tank something to do on his turn.Overall Story is a +, game balance is a -.  Take your pick on which is more important to you.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												Solid, enjoyable, well put-together game.The game's difficulty on Normal is a bit too easy, although Hard mode presents a decent challenge, especially earlier on in the game (before you get access to the really OP debuffs).Despite the RPG Maker feel that a lot of people seem to detest, Skyborn's a very polished package.  I noticed a couple small bugs and a couple typos, but that was it on the negatives.I was able to play this with a controller, which was very appreciated.  I used a 3rd party knockoff Xbox360 controller, which didn't require any additional setup upon booting the game.  However, I was able to hit F1 in-game and remap the buttons to something more sensible, the defaults didn't make sense on my particular controller.Dialogue was well-written, enjoyable, and fairly humorous.  Plot, while a bit short, was interesting and flowed well.  Combat system had a nice brisk pace, with good yet swift animations for attacks.The leveling and itemization was a stand-out success, in my mind: armor is equippable by all characters, but if you weigh a character down beyond their carrying capacity, their speed drops off.  There are a few ways of increasing that capacity later in the game.  But that broad eligibility allows a much wider amount of equipment options for each character, as you can trade off weight between different slots to equip items you REALLY want.  The augment system is simple yet robust, offering another layer of customizibility to your characters.  Furthermore, there are two "class up"s during the game, where you can upgrade each character to a new job class.  The game does a great job of explaining the options prior to selection, so you don't need to consult a third party resource for information.It took me about 15 hours to complete the game, playing in hard mode and completing all optional content&bosses.  I'm a bit of a slow player, though, so most folks will probably take about 7-12 depending on difficulty and completeness.I don't think I'd pay the full $15 for this one due to its length, but at sale prices it's a great purchase.Enjoy!

Posted: February 24, 2016
												I don't actually remember buying this game, and when I found it in my library and played it I was pleasantly surpised. It's surprisingly well written, and the gameplay is well balanced.The gameplay is far from revolutionary, apart from the 'threat'-mechanic which I've never seen before, but works really well and is nicely streamlined. It's well balanced, but some areas lack a little polish. That's acceptable since it was made by a small team, and it never breaks the game in any way. The soundtrack is nothing revolutionary either, but at least it's nice music and it fits the settings it plays in.The main characters are well written and realtable. The game succeeded in making me like the heroes and at least disliking the villains enough that I agree with the ultimate goal the heroes are working towards. The story is not overly dramatic, it doesn't try desperately to be funny all the time, and it's not all grim or lighthearted. It introduces characters at a good pace and gives them space to develop over time.This game is like a good fantasy-steampunk book, with monster slaying in between every chapter. The game succeedes in really feeling like an adventure, but it never loses sight of the end goal.

Posted: May 27, 2015
												A rather well-written game. Most of the foes are easily recognizable, spelled slightly differently yet are similar to familiar monsters from myths and legends (and D&D). The story itself, though cliche in some parts, still has some interesting twists to it.There are elements of romance, but unlike the Aveyond series, Skyborn is too short for any serious romances to develop. Enthralling but short would be good for it - also, unlike many RPG games, one of the biggest Pro's for Skyborn: Grinding isn't needed. Or rather, enemies do not respawn, yet there are many "exploration" points out there, similar to revealing a new map location in an MMORPG, that grant a considerable amount of experience to your party.

Posted: June 7, 2015
												I give this a recommend, but only a slight one. The game play is short, but works. The characters are nice, although somewhat predictable. What got me was that my party was slowly becoming a glass cannon. You can easily avoid monsters, and there is no obvious leveling ground. As such, I started my "no turning back now", and was able to easily make it to the end boss, including killing all the bosses within the area before the final boss.But then, the final boss has an AOE that one shots my entire party. So that is my only complaint, that you really need to attack monsters while going through, don't avoid them. If you do, you can easily end up not knowing the end of the game because the last boss is just so much more powerful.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												Skyborn is a short RPGMaker-made game that's very good looking (in the japanese anime classical style) and has great music.  It exposes interracial and social classes conflicts in a steampunk-fantasy sort of environment. The story is good but the arcs of the characters' stories are not very complicated and there are no important choices to make or crossroads where several endings can develop.Fights are not at every corner of an alley because you can visually choose (most of the times) if you fight enemies or you just ignore them. The story/fighting ratio is well balanced, but while some generic enemies are a piece of cake some bosses are a pain in the mouse's left button. By the way, while some enemies' design goes according to the world presented, some others seem to have been taken out of other very different projects.Gameplay is easy either with a keyboard or with the mouse, but the UI both in the character menus and in battle is a little bit of a mess and if you pause the game for a long time you will have to re-learn almost everything. Fights are repetitive and turn-based and the special effects are not outstanding but acceptable. You can upgrade your characters' classes and abbilities but even then some of they are left behind while others grow.I recommend Skyborn if you like classical J-turn-based-RPGs and you are not too exigent.

Moreover, the game seems a little rushed, there are very interesting characters that just vanish. Finaly, some people may think that the developer had more in mind for this world but it `needed to get done`.

Posted: May 23, 2016
												I guess I'm now about 4-5 hours into this game, and I can say that I'm really enjoying it. This comes from one who has almost given up on RPG maker games. Skyborn is a game well done. While I don't anticipate it being very long, I think it should be just long enough. The story is good. The fighting system is good. The music is great. The level of polish is great! At this point, the game has given hints of secrets and things to keep the player busy well after the main quest. There is a coliseum in which I died on my first fight, a whole series of shops reserved for high level people in the Coliseum. I also believe there is probably a bonus dungeon, based upon things the NPCs say. The maker of the game has put a lot of effort into this game. While I would assume the RPG Maker program has it's limitations, at moments, I simply forget this is a RPGM game. The game does not have random enemy encounters. Instead, there are a limited number of on screen enemies. This puts a limit on the experience and gold one can earn. This puts grinding to a minimum and makes the player figure out how to use the system to beat the bosses. The only negatives I can mention is that nearly ALL RPG Maker games have moments of slowdown on my computer for some reason. I can run Skyrim at good FPS, but I think the performance problem is rooted in RPGM and my hardware. I can't fault the maker for that. The other thing, is that despite this game having what seems to be a pretty straightforward crafting system, I have no idea what I'm crafting and how much of each material the thing I am crafting takes. It says, "200% more ore" but doesn't tell me exactly how much of what. Perhaps I've missed something early on in the game. Other than that, I can gladly say that this is a great game. There are moments when the story, the action, and the music all come together to a near final fantasy level moment. Since then, I now have Deadly Sin and Deadly Sin 2. I've also got my eye on Echoes of Aetheria. One last thing, I believe I picked this game by either Humble Bundle or one of the bundle sites. If it were not for that, I never would have heard of it. I am glad I came across this gem!

												A nice little RPG for the price. The game really ramps up in difficulty after about 5 hours in playing on the hardest difficulty. For a while I had actually forgot I was playing on the hardest difficulty. At this point there were several fights that had me worried I might actually have to restart from my save. After getting the current tier armor and weapons upgraded and augmented I still have one or two party members go down each fight. Steel Slimes hit like a truck >.> Boss fights up to this point have been fairly simple with them dying in a round or two. I have yet to fight a boss since the difficulty curve has been upped. If the regular monster battles are any indicator it is going to be very difficult. There is also a little bit of humor in the game that I find quite enjoyable. Storytelling is pretty good as well.Overall I am quite pleased with this game.

Posted: March 15, 2014
												I wasn't expecting much when I started up Skyborn, but was pleasantly surprised almost immediately. It has a very well-developed and likable cast of characters. The combat and game mechanics are just deep enough to make you plan things out, but intuitive enough that you'll know what you're doing right away. I especially enjoyed the Augment system, which allows you to add various effects to your gear and dramatically improve their usefulness. The music is also very well done, enough that I would even be willing to pick up a soundtrack. The story isn't anything spectacular, but it's simple and engaging enough to keep you interested for the entire length of the game (which was about 11 hours, including all of the sidequests). The adjustable difficulty level is also extremely useful, because with a bit of planning and sidequesting, you can become pretty much unstoppable and render most end-game foes meaningless.All in all, I give this an 8/10, and definitely recommend it for anyone looking for a good retro-style RPG.

Posted: March 10, 2014
												A charming little RPG combining past and present gameplay elements -- it appeals to both casual players new to the genre or just in it for the story and core players who want to dedicate hours grinding, item hunting, and beating side bosses.  For a game easily beatable in under 12 hours, the game has quite a few memorable moments.  Dialogue is well-written and scenes both comical and tragic actually hit home.  The story is somewhat standard but with occasional twists and turns, and there's so much optional content that you can easily draw the game out for a few more hours if you like.  The game definitely lives up to its reputation of being reminiscent of old-school entries in the Final Fantasy and Mana series of games, but visual effects and in game interfaces do also have a modern aesthetic.  You may not want to pay full price considering the short length and lack of replay value, but this is definitely a good choice for any real fan of the genre, and a fantastic snag if found on sale!
