Posted: December 23, 2015
												Skyborn is a game that was made with love by a handful of people with a Steampunk feel that's made with the RPG Maker suite of tools.  It's one of the best games ever made with that suit (to my mind) and I finished it in roughly 12 hours of play.  It's not that long.  I've played around 10 or 11 RPG Maker games, and I've always found it to be one of the better gaming experiences.  Skyborn has a lot of things going for it.  The game works pretty smoothly, the plot and setting are very interesting and different from a lot of boring "Dragon Warrior" or "Final Fantasy" clones.  The game has levels of difficulty I didn't expect, and the game is pretty standard fare for the engine.The major character is a tinker and engineer lady who's had it pretty okay under the thumbs of the ruling class Skyborn that look like draconians from Dragonlance.  As she is set on her explorations, she finds a lot of people who have it worse than she did.  And she'll rally some folks to the cause, and set out to bring down the big bad and some of the Skyborn race.  If you just want a diverting throwback to the mechanics of old, but with modern settings, story-telling and concepts, then Skyborn is a pretty satisfying way to spend some time.  I enjoyed the time that I invested into the game.

Posted: December 23, 2015
												Let me tldr my review: This game's story is one of the best I've encountered from an independent studio, and the mechanics itself work quite well. But my experience has not been a positive one. I may keep playing just to enjoy the story, but probably not on my pc if I do. My experience may not happen for everyone, but I can only speak for my experience.For the rest of you.I want to love this game. I do. I really do. But the design choices that have been made are pretty bad and the excuses made for them even moreso. 640X800 is not an acceptable visual resolution in 2015, or in 2014, or in 2013, or in fact any time in the past decade. To hard code it at that level seems almost preposterous. We can blame the system he used to craft this game all we and he wants, but I have played a good number of RPGmaker games and they all worked just fine in higher resolutions. Going on isn't explaining, so let's explain. When I enter fullscreen mode, a good 1/6 of the screen becomes invisible. Unfortunately, it's the part of the screen where all the buttons are. This appears to be hardcoded. I have tried a number of solutions to make the screen fit into my monitor, and none have worked.So I could play it in windowed mode? Yes, but windowed mode is not resizable. And I've not had much luck in moving it around the screen, either. More importantly, I don't like playing in windowed mode and I resent being told that is my only choice.You may be asking. why is this a big deal? Well, it isn't, strawman. It is not a big deal. It is, however, enough of one. The market is full. Crowded to the brim with games as good or almost as good as this, many of them almost as well written or even better written. When it comes to things like this, everyone decides their own place to draw the line, and this is mine.I already own the game, I wouldn't return it if I could, and I wish the developers all the best in their future endeavours. But I cannot recommend this game.

												I am an old school gamer and I played a tone of old style RPG games and this one really takes me back at least to the super Nintendo years. this game really has a lot to offer really good sound track. an unusual but interesting combat system. this game has a really solid story line and the dialogue is also quite good. most games like this have serious dialog issues and they sound corny or just silly so its nice to play a game that has a nice flow to it. Posted: March 8, 2015
												Overall, I was pretty happy with this game. The fighting system is well made, and enjoyable. The puzzles (lever/button mazes) are just long enough to require some thought, but not so long that they are unpleasant. The story is well done, if short. And the weapon augmenting system made equipping characters highly customizable and fun. If you don't do the extra content, the end dungeon and boss are very, very hard (even just on normal mode). But if you do the extra dungeon and colluseum all the way through, you will have no problems with it. Also, make sure to use the 2 fruits you are given during specific points in the game. I thought they were just for a free level up, but they're actually how you learn your next sets of skills. The bonus dungeon (Venom Depths) can be found by taking the red portal on the celestial elevators from the poorest town in the bottom lefthand corner, it has a stone formation on either side of it.

Posted: March 23, 2015
Skyborn is an RPG in the style of classic SNES-era JRPG's. It's fairly typical to the genre, but I found that it had some nice tweaks that kept it interesting.The turn-based combat system features "threat" for each party member, which rises as that character does more damage against enemies. Enemies will always attack the party member with the highest threat, leading to some interesting decisions. The characters' special abilities were varied and each party member felt unique. Buffs, debuffs, and other status changes were key to winning battles, so I didn't feel like I was just constantly tapping the button to attack. Several times during the game the characters will be able to upgrade their class, with each of the options granting different new abilities.There are no random battles, but instead monsters wander around the map. Once they are defeated, they're gone forever, so you can't really over-grind. Leveling up doesn't increase your stats all that much anyway, and most of your stat boosts will come from new equipment. Equipment can be forged from various stones found in the environment and further augmented with gems and other items.The story involves the conflicts of ground-dwelling humans and winged skyborn who are gifted with magical abilities. It kept me playing and had a few unexpected twists, but wasn't anything truly ground-breaking.I first started the game on Normal difficulty, but after finding a few battles too easy I switched over to Hard. I found battles much more interesting on this setting and I kept it this way until the very end of the game. The second-to-last boss kept destroying my entire party before they could take any actions. As I was at the point of no return with no way to get better equipment, I could either load up an earlier save, or decrease the difficulty level. I chose the latter. Reading the game's author's comments on Steam, it looks like defeating the final bosses on Hard would have required a lot more effort, so my regret over this decision is minimal.If you're looking for a relatively-short classic JRPG with a few modern twists, I'd definitely recommend giving Skyborn a shot. It's been bundled several times and I expect it to do so again, so you should be able to find it for cheap.

Posted: January 30, 2015
												So I'll admit, when I first saw this game my thoughts were "Another RPG maker game…great.” But I got it and played it all the way through.First I shall start with the cons:  It took 9 hours to beat….THAT’S IT!!! NO other cons!! I loved it so so so much!! This game! Seriously the best JRPG I have played in a LONG time. Since most JRPG’s basically have the same mechanics, the thing that sets them apart is their story, so the story has a huge impact on a JRPG. A great story makes a great JRPG in my opinion, and this game’s story was fantastic!  I won’t go into it, because I want you to go and experience it for yourself! It starts off a little generic and slow, but it speeds up fast, and the world that is built is amazing.As for mechanics, there are two things I loved. First, in battle, there is a component called Threat, and a party member’s threat goes up based on the strength of their attacks, and killing enemies. The enemies will attack the party member with the most threat, so it adds an extra level of strategy. You can have a character who is a heavy hitter but can’t take hits, so you have to strategize to have your tank build up their threat so they can take hits for them. Second, the game rewards you for exploring. If you look around the world you will find little nodes hidden away at dead ends and tricky spots, which reward you with EXP which helps you level up. Also the chests have some great loot as well.Like I said, I wasn’t expecting it to be so short. When playing these kind of games you expect long an epic, and lingering story that has so many unsuspecting pit falls and delays, but this game had its story short sweet and to the point, which I have to say worked out nicely for it in the end. I really loved it.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												I couldn't remove a selection and I couldn't make an intermediate selection so I went with yes.  I enjoyed playing the game for the most part.  The story may use a tried and true plot device, but it does contain a few twists that I, at least, didn't see coming.  The world is fairly small, but most of the areas are very diversified so it doesn't feel that way.  Also the smithing is a nice touch, though I would have liked to make higher quality armor as well. My problem with the game was the combat balance.  For one I almost immediately turned the game up to hard.  This is something I almost never do as I generally like to keep combat just difficult enough that I keep interested without becoming a hassle.  On Normal there was absolutely no challenge.  For most random encounters that didn't change much on Hard.  Boss battles, came in two varities: 'What just wiped me in 2 seconds' or 'what did I just roll over.'  There are certain skills in the game (For you and your enemies) that are just ridiculously strong.  But if you don't use them, then battles just drag on because at least with how I was building characters (trying to emphasize +Str as much as I could!) only 1-2 of my characters ever did appreciable amounts of damage.  Also the character classes are very specialized. Only certain people dealt damage, and at times it really felt the only reason "threat" existed was to give the tank something to do on his turn.Overall Story is a +, game balance is a -.  Take your pick on which is more important to you.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												Played through this in about six hours; in one sitting.  Why in one sitting, you ask?  Because I couldn't tear myself away!  The story here does a rather good job of telling itself during that six hours(which could be four or less if you're in a hurry).  It's a fairly nuanced tale with all the proper tragic hero tropes, plot twists and surprise endings, but it doesn't do a lot of padding to get there.  If you're looking for any kind of gameplay balance, do speed runs.  Otherwise this game is incredibly easy even on its hardest settings, although there is one battle you will never win ;).All in all, for $7.49 (at half price) I felt like I got my money's worth and then some.  This is a rather well-polished RPGmaker gem that will leave you wanting more from this developer in the future!

Posted: February 25, 2014
												Solid, enjoyable, well put-together game.The game's difficulty on Normal is a bit too easy, although Hard mode presents a decent challenge, especially earlier on in the game (before you get access to the really OP debuffs).Despite the RPG Maker feel that a lot of people seem to detest, Skyborn's a very polished package.  I noticed a couple small bugs and a couple typos, but that was it on the negatives.I was able to play this with a controller, which was very appreciated.  I used a 3rd party knockoff Xbox360 controller, which didn't require any additional setup upon booting the game.  However, I was able to hit F1 in-game and remap the buttons to something more sensible, the defaults didn't make sense on my particular controller.Dialogue was well-written, enjoyable, and fairly humorous.  Plot, while a bit short, was interesting and flowed well.  Combat system had a nice brisk pace, with good yet swift animations for attacks.The leveling and itemization was a stand-out success, in my mind: armor is equippable by all characters, but if you weigh a character down beyond their carrying capacity, their speed drops off.  There are a few ways of increasing that capacity later in the game.  But that broad eligibility allows a much wider amount of equipment options for each character, as you can trade off weight between different slots to equip items you REALLY want.  The augment system is simple yet robust, offering another layer of customizibility to your characters.  Furthermore, there are two "class up"s during the game, where you can upgrade each character to a new job class.  The game does a great job of explaining the options prior to selection, so you don't need to consult a third party resource for information.It took me about 15 hours to complete the game, playing in hard mode and completing all optional content&bosses.  I'm a bit of a slow player, though, so most folks will probably take about 7-12 depending on difficulty and completeness.I don't think I'd pay the full $15 for this one due to its length, but at sale prices it's a great purchase.Enjoy!

Posted: March 1, 2014
												For a casual RPG player like myself, Skyborn was a wonderful little game with a poignant story, fun gameplay, and quick pace.  There was never a need for tedious grinding--in fact, you could avoid most battles if you wanted to, but I don't know how that would affect your leveling.  Shops were placed conveniently between stretches of dungeon to buy (or make) better weapons and armor.  You could also buy supplies, although the plentiful item chests usually provided enough for me.  Some areas (Nordenwald Forest *cough*) were rather lengthy with extended puzzles involving painful walking from one end of the map to the other.  Aside from the particularly grueling dungeon and the utter lack of promised side quests, Skyborn proved to be a short but delightful game.  I'll certainly be replaying it in the future to try different class combinations and fighting styles.

Posted: February 3, 2015
												I recommend Skyborn, but I don't recommend it strongly.  There are a few important things to know about it.1) Skyborn is pretty fun.If you like oldschool RPGs -- and I mean Might and Magic 1/Final Fantast 1 oldschool, you'll probably like the system and combat style.2) Skyborn is pretty.The art really is good.  The game is guilty of using a lot of pallet swaps, but everything is pretty appealing to look at (unless, of course, it's not supposed to be)3) Skyborn has a really wonky difficulty and progress flowThis is a game that will, pretty randomly, decide to kick your♥♥♥♥♥or be a cakewalk.  In that way, the design behind it isn't really great.  What's more, the game itself doesn't have a whole lot of flow to it: there are♥♥♥♥♥numbingly long dungeon segments, but then there are segments that go by FAST.4) Skyborn is short.I don't know if I missed a ton of game somewhere, other than grinding to do the arena sidequest, but the endgame difficulty seems to suggest that no, I didn't.  It really doesn't have a lot to it.  What there is is good, but it isn't long.  I guess that's alright, since a game that's too long can easily overstay its welcome, and I've known plenty of games to be both good and short, but part of me wanted more out of Skyborn.  I guess looking at my time logged I have to say it's not REALLY short, just shorter than you might expect out of a game of the genre.So, from that you can probably tell whether you'd like Skyborn or not.  It's got a good look and feel and a good plot, but a few flaws that I don't really mind, but that might be dealbreakers for some.

												JRPG. Character sprites and portraits are attractive and well-animated. If you liked the original Final Fantasy, I think you'll like this too. Took me 11 hours to finish; short but satisfying.I'm a completionist, so I accepted every single random battle and got every side quest and searched every nook. If you want to do the minimum possible, you may have trouble with the boss battles later on.Battle is turn-based. Some MMO elements: threat and energy generation. There's an in-game tutorial but I ended up skipping it entirely. There are many buffs and debuffs, so much so that it's easy to lose track-- names aren't terribly intuitive either, e.g. Majesty is a debuff?Character and gear stats are fairly opaque; I used a GameFAQs guide to figure things out. UI is clunky when it comes to gear stats. It's difficult to see the stats on equipped gear; Equip and Augment pages aren't laid out very well.

Posted: March 8, 2015
												Overall, I was pretty happy with this game. The fighting system is well made, and enjoyable. The puzzles (lever/button mazes) are just long enough to require some thought, but not so long that they are unpleasant. The story is well done, if short. And the weapon augmenting system made equipping characters highly customizable and fun. If you don't do the extra content, the end dungeon and boss are very, very hard (even just on normal mode). But if you do the extra dungeon and colluseum all the way through, you will have no problems with it. Also, make sure to use the 2 fruits you are given during specific points in the game. I thought they were just for a free level up, but they're actually how you learn your next sets of skills. The bonus dungeon (Venom Depths) can be found by taking the red portal on the celestial elevators from the poorest town in the bottom lefthand corner, it has a stone formation on either side of it.

Posted: October 13, 2015
												LOVED This game. It took me about 8 hours to clear (I played in offline mode on my laptop for half of it). The combat is balanced and the characters are interesting and all useful in their own way. All characters are customizable from picking which skills they learn, to choosing equipment, to finally choosing which item/buff to apply to each piece of equipment. Building up my characters was the funnest part. The combat is interesting. It has a threat system where enemies focus on the party members doing the flashiest moves. Exploring the game world is vastly rewarding and encouraged. Not only do you find great gear, but you can find experience points by exploring. The game also has additional side content that I didnt complete in my 8 hour playthrough. This includes, a fighting arena, a side dungeon to explore, and finding a deck of cards that has been scattered across the land. My only complaint is that the weapon/armor crafting system in this game seems tacked on and forgettable. The items you can craft are limited and you usually have them by the time you can craft them anyway. Having said that, this is a game that no RPG fan should miss out on. 9.5/10

Posted: September 27, 2015
												An interesting and compelling game from start to finish. Skyborn is an RPG-Maker made game with it's unique style, the environments throught the game are very well detailed which just goes to show how much work and time the developers put on it. The game is very story-driven so if you're not so much into story and more into constant action this isn't the game for you. The characters are well designed, each one having it's unique objective and background explained in the game through constant flashbacks, which in turn translates into a nice storytelling. Skyborn features a crafting system which allows you to craft armors and weapons from ores you pick along the way and an augment system which allows you to enchant them, the system itself is really simple but at the same time really addicting and you'll find yourself more often than not looking at every wall in search of ores (I know I did!). Not all is good about the game however. Some changes to the battle system for example (which still features some RPG-Maker standard sprites and grid system) could have been explored way better. The mouse feature, here strangely introduced, also doesn't make much sense for this kind of game, you'll find out that using the mouse will only make things more complicated and unnatural, luckily the developers added an option in the menu to toggle on/off the mouse feature. Achievements for Steam also not supported which is actually a real bummer since you have so much to achieve in this game! Oh well :)Overall a great game with over 12+ hours of content to explore, be it sidequesting, following the main story line or crafting in your free time. Congratulations to the developers. 8/10

Posted: December 20, 2015
												I got this game free from Bundle Stars and finally got around to playing it. I really enjoyed the story and the mechanics of the game. While it seemed a bit short there are some extra side quests put in that extend it a bit. The game can probably be finished in under 12 hours. I spent more time doing the side quests and trying to kill every enemy I could find. There are a finite number of enemies in the game so you can only level up so much. Wasn't really a problem as I was able to easily run through the last leg of the game without any trouble. I did consult a guide but you probably don't need to unless you are trying to collect all the spade cards. Don't forget to hit up the arena, I almost missed it. You get some good loot there.

Posted: December 23, 2015
												Skyborn is a game that was made with love by a handful of people with a Steampunk feel that's made with the RPG Maker suite of tools.  It's one of the best games ever made with that suit (to my mind) and I finished it in roughly 12 hours of play.  It's not that long.  I've played around 10 or 11 RPG Maker games, and I've always found it to be one of the better gaming experiences.  Skyborn has a lot of things going for it.  The game works pretty smoothly, the plot and setting are very interesting and different from a lot of boring "Dragon Warrior" or "Final Fantasy" clones.  The game has levels of difficulty I didn't expect, and the game is pretty standard fare for the engine.The major character is a tinker and engineer lady who's had it pretty okay under the thumbs of the ruling class Skyborn that look like draconians from Dragonlance.  As she is set on her explorations, she finds a lot of people who have it worse than she did.  And she'll rally some folks to the cause, and set out to bring down the big bad and some of the Skyborn race.  If you just want a diverting throwback to the mechanics of old, but with modern settings, story-telling and concepts, then Skyborn is a pretty satisfying way to spend some time.  I enjoyed the time that I invested into the game.

Posted: December 22, 2015
												I played through it once from beginning to end. Not very complicated, but it's not meant to be. Good story, great artwork. I haven't been more enthralled in a game for a long time, and, frankly, it was refreshing. The towns blew me away. They're all unique. The game does have flaws, specifically, the Colliseum bosses and the final optional boss in the last dungeon were both rather up there in difficulty, and I was surprised by the last minute appearance of platinum ore. Very disappointing in that I was unable to use the platinum ore. Combat was straightforward, but got a little boring after awhile. The side quests were cute! Unfortunately, I only found a couple and I wanted more! In all honesty, these complaints are minor and I feel like I'm nitpicking. For $15 ($1.53/hr over 10 hours)? Worth it.

Posted: December 23, 2015
												Let me tldr my review: This game's story is one of the best I've encountered from an independent studio, and the mechanics itself work quite well. But my experience has not been a positive one. I may keep playing just to enjoy the story, but probably not on my pc if I do. My experience may not happen for everyone, but I can only speak for my experience.For the rest of you.I want to love this game. I do. I really do. But the design choices that have been made are pretty bad and the excuses made for them even moreso. 640X800 is not an acceptable visual resolution in 2015, or in 2014, or in 2013, or in fact any time in the past decade. To hard code it at that level seems almost preposterous. We can blame the system he used to craft this game all we and he wants, but I have played a good number of RPGmaker games and they all worked just fine in higher resolutions. Going on isn't explaining, so let's explain. When I enter fullscreen mode, a good 1/6 of the screen becomes invisible. Unfortunately, it's the part of the screen where all the buttons are. This appears to be hardcoded. I have tried a number of solutions to make the screen fit into my monitor, and none have worked.So I could play it in windowed mode? Yes, but windowed mode is not resizable. And I've not had much luck in moving it around the screen, either. More importantly, I don't like playing in windowed mode and I resent being told that is my only choice.You may be asking. why is this a big deal? Well, it isn't, strawman. It is not a big deal. It is, however, enough of one. The market is full. Crowded to the brim with games as good or almost as good as this, many of them almost as well written or even better written. When it comes to things like this, everyone decides their own place to draw the line, and this is mine.I already own the game, I wouldn't return it if I could, and I wish the developers all the best in their future endeavours. But I cannot recommend this game.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												I've played hundreds of RPGs over the last 25 years.  There's nothing unique or revolutionary about this game, but it's definitely a step above most games developed using RPGMaker.  Despite the short length, I feel I got my money's worth.Pros:  - All primary characters are engaging, relatable, and offer unique contributions to group combat.  - Combat includes a "Threat" mechanic, based on how much damage or healing is done by each group member. Monsters focus single-target attacks on the character with the most threat.  This lets you build a team with the traditional tank, healer and damage dealers, rather than just a bunch of toons with high stats that bang on mobs until they're all dead.  - Enjoyable storyline.  I also liked how the backstory was introduced.  There's more groups involved in the conflict than just humans and Skyborn.  - No bugs, glitches or typos.  - There's no grinding.  There's only a fixed number of monsters in the game, which are visible on the map and avoidable if you choose.  Instead, the game offers an alternative: "exploration nodes".  These grant experience (as though you won a combat), rewarding those who focus more on exploring.  - Several secondary conquests, including a gladiator arena and a deep dungeon with additional challenges.  - Forge mechanic.  You can collect some materials (iron, coal, platina) throughout the game and use it to craft some weapons and armor.Cons:  - Preferred more character development for the antagonists, villains, and that one mysterious girl who talks about being hungry.  You'll know who I mean. :)  - Length of gameplay: only about 15-20 hours.  This is on par with old school 90s RPGs like Final Fantasy IV, Chrono Trigger, and Secret of Mana... although those 3 games felt like they have far deeper, more drawn out stories compared to this game.  - Lack of difficulty.  I played the game on Hard (max) difficulty and there wasn't much challenge, other than a little bad luck with RNG on a few midgame bosses.  - Lack of challenging puzzles.  It's mainly just finding the right buttons to open passages.  - Lack of side quests.  I found only one actual side quest (the rest were part of the main storyline).  - Not much actual exploration involved.  Lack of open world feel.  Game is fairly linear.Final Rating: 8 / 10

Posted: July 13, 2016
												TL;DR: Yes, yes, yes. Will follow developer's new games. Buy on sale if possible.Just finished this game last night. I enjoyed it so I feel a sense of obligation to write my thoughts on it for others.I was impressed by this game, especially being a RPGmaker game. Every setting was decorated beautifully! I found myself appreciating every new screen my characters would visit and could tell the developers took some time to make everything look nice. The storyline was really good as well, and story line progression was at a good pace so that I wouldn't get too restless on each quest.There are quite a few ways the game could have been improved, such as the combat system, forgery, side quests, and "hidden gems" but honestly I'm too lazy to get into details about those :PAlso, I got it during the Steam Summer sale and I firmly believe it was well worth the money. It took me about 10 hours with a leisurely playstyle and on and off. The current price of $14.99 is a bit high in my opinion, even though the game was beautiful so if you can get it on a sale, that'd be great.

 "Is a good/regular oldstyle rpg game"  Talking a bit about everything Has a good story, the graphics are simple and "oldstyle" probably your pcmasterrace machine won't use even 10% of it's power but for me is ok it really remembers me of the old games I used to play, I liked the music, the combat is really what you would spect, simple 2D images getting impacted by your attacks (like a pokemon fight, not pokemon go, just pokemon...). Good classic gameplay  I really liked this game, while I played it I felt very good, having a slow game with a good story is unusual this days but was really good to play it, every time I was stressed and no one was playing anything I just started playing this and in a short period of time I completed it. The price... I got it for free  According to the actual price of the game it costs $14.99 in my opinion this is a high price for this game, but probably (not entirely sure) the game during steam sales should be around half the price and at that point (around $7.5) for me it would be a good price, but if it is even lower than that I would grab it.

Posted: September 17, 2015
												REVIEW:While very skeptical when first acquiring the game, I decided to give it a go and was not let down. Very similar to the RPGs of old, those seeking to re-enter that kind of world won't be let down either!Story - While perhaps not the most deep story ever written for an RPG, it certainly wasn't bad. It had, to me, plenty of depth for the length of the game as a whole. It also had a good amount of all the story elements one would look for. While it wasn't necessarily evoking particular emotions for me, it might for you. I give the story a solid 8/10.Audio - The sound track for the game was particularly good, which caught me by surprise. I never found myself thinking "Man, this track is annoying..." and muting the sound. Do you remember how Chrono Trigger's amazing sound track really set the atmosphere for the different areas in the game? Skyborn does the same. I give the audio a well-deserved 10/10.Visual - Again, this game takes me back. There's nostalgia everywhere. With that in mind, the graphics, sprites, artwork, etc. don't let down. Very pleasing to the eye, in every area of the game. I can't think of an area or situation in which I thought something looked like it could have been done better. The different artwork and visual effects all fit in their respective areas, and paired with the music really brought everything together. Visuals get a 10/10 from me as well.Gameplay - Here's where I get really nitpicky. There are a few things here that could be done better, so I'll list them in no particular order:1. Mouse controls - During battles (which were handled great! no random battles!), I found myself accidentally clicking on an option I didn't intend to. For example, a few times I misclicked and ended up "Guarding" on a turn that I needed to do something else... because the curser was "stuck" on the icon beside it. It's kind of hard to describe, but if you're careful it isn't too much of an issue.2. DEBUFFS - This one is a major gripe for me. You can track buffs/debuffs on your party with a visual alert in the upper-right corner of their portraits. Enemy debuffs, however, you have to deliberately watch for "-DebuffName" to appear in text near the bottom of their image when it wears off. This can be very, very debilitating to your plans if a necessary debuff (Majesty, for example) falls off without you noticing it... which is very possible if the enemy uses some form of buff that either removes it, or grants them all kinds of buffs and your debuffs just happen to fall on off that turn anyway.For future games, I would most definitely recommend some kind of visual aid for enemy debuffs, if possible. Granted, there was really only a few situaions where it was of dire importance that I had to keep track of enemy debuffs, but it meant a party wipe (no joke) if one fell off and I didn't notice.3. Difficulty - Not necessarily a gripe, but also not necessarily something I can comment on entirely. The game has 3 different combat difficulties: Easy, Medium (Normal?), and Hard. I played through the game on Normal, and found it to be far too easy in parts. I haven't played through it again on Hard, so I can't comment on Hard mode; however, given the resources available to you, "Normal" difficulty becomes a little too easy. (Except for a few parts, but I'm not going to spoil anything here.)4. Game Length - I put in 15 hours to this game before completion. This is with about a 99% completion rate. While 15 hours is a far cry from the 50 to 60 hours a game like Chrono Trigger or Final Fantasy 3 (6) had with a similar completion rate, it was pretty generous for this game. Also note that about 4 of those hours are me back-tracking in the damned forest.With those small issues in mind, I'm going with an 8/10 on the gameplay. It had everything I liked, a little more, but also a few issues I feel could have been handled better.VERDICT:Over all, I give Skyborn a 9/10, and a high recommendation to anyone who grew up with the great RPGs from the SNES era, who are looking for a piece of nostalgic greatness. A true diamond in the rough, I really hope to see more like this from the developers. (Even a sequel would be great!)

Posted: June 30, 2016
												Tidy little RPG. 100%'d on Hard Mode in about 15 hours. Early game didn't impress me, but the characters and art were enjoyable enough that I stuck with it. Glad I did. Late-game provided delightful tactical challenges, and the story, while not particularly complex, was solid.Took actual effort to complete the optional bosses and defeat the final boss—effort, not just time. There is no grinding in this game, since there's a finite amount of enemies. They don't respawn. You can't farm.The balance was just right for it, though. Even when I was slightly over the power curve, enemies in most areas were still able to present a tangible threat, and as noted, the final boss was a real challenge even after completing optional challenges. I had to optimize my resources very carefully in order to avoid retries.Oh, and you get to retry a fight you lost instead of just falling back to your latest save, which is nice. Saved me a lot of time against some of the tougher enemies.Come for the steampunk. Stay for the characters. Leave proud of your accomplishments.

Posted: May 23, 2016
												I guess I'm now about 4-5 hours into this game, and I can say that I'm really enjoying it. This comes from one who has almost given up on RPG maker games. Skyborn is a game well done. While I don't anticipate it being very long, I think it should be just long enough. The story is good. The fighting system is good. The music is great. The level of polish is great! At this point, the game has given hints of secrets and things to keep the player busy well after the main quest. There is a coliseum in which I died on my first fight, a whole series of shops reserved for high level people in the Coliseum. I also believe there is probably a bonus dungeon, based upon things the NPCs say. The maker of the game has put a lot of effort into this game. While I would assume the RPG Maker program has it's limitations, at moments, I simply forget this is a RPGM game. The game does not have random enemy encounters. Instead, there are a limited number of on screen enemies. This puts a limit on the experience and gold one can earn. This puts grinding to a minimum and makes the player figure out how to use the system to beat the bosses. The only negatives I can mention is that nearly ALL RPG Maker games have moments of slowdown on my computer for some reason. I can run Skyrim at good FPS, but I think the performance problem is rooted in RPGM and my hardware. I can't fault the maker for that. The other thing, is that despite this game having what seems to be a pretty straightforward crafting system, I have no idea what I'm crafting and how much of each material the thing I am crafting takes. It says, "200% more ore" but doesn't tell me exactly how much of what. Perhaps I've missed something early on in the game. Other than that, I can gladly say that this is a great game. There are moments when the story, the action, and the music all come together to a near final fantasy level moment. Since then, I now have Deadly Sin and Deadly Sin 2. I've also got my eye on Echoes of Aetheria. One last thing, I believe I picked this game by either Humble Bundle or one of the bundle sites. If it were not for that, I never would have heard of it. I am glad I came across this gem!

Posted: March 7, 2016
												Skyborn is a turn-based RPG in the vein of old-school RPGs like Final Fantasy. You control a band of characters that are trying to save the world from the tyrannical yadda yadda yadda, you know the drill. It was all made with RPG Maker, but don't let that turn you off -- I'd say it's worth a look.I found this game rather charming. While the plot, music, and graphics aren't the newest and shiniest things ever, everything is good quality and holds together well enough for me to enjoy playing through it -- I even want to run through it again later. There are moments between characters to establish them more beyond "insert hero person here", and the world combines steampunk with a more standard fantasy setting in a way that's enjoyable, with more going on than is apparent at first. While there might not be a whole lot more to do than just the main story, there are some sidequests for players who poke around looking for extra treasure, and there's a crafting/augment system for people who want to micromanage their equipment a bit more.The battle system is pretty fun to work with -- each character has a threat level that rises as they do damage, and whoever has the highest threat will be soaking up most of the attacks. The key is to make sure the tankiest character in your group keeps their threat level the highest (easier said than done, at times!), and I feel it works fairly well. Most fights are fairly simple, though there are some trickier fights later in the game -- the final boss and bonus boss in particular are pretty darn hard to deal with.All in all, I'd say give this game a try if a charming little steampunk/fantasy turn-based RPG with fun characters and a neat battle system sounds interesting to you.

While I don't anticipate it being very long, I think it should be just long enough. The story is good. The fighting system is good. The music is great. The level of polish is great! Instead, there are a limited number of on screen enemies. This puts a limit on the experience and gold one can earn. This puts grinding to a minimum and makes the player figure out how to use the system to beat the bosses. The only negatives I can mention is that nearly ALL RPG Maker games have moments of slowdown on my computer for some reason. I can run Skyrim at good FPS, but I think the performance problem is rooted in RPGM and my hardware. I can't fault the maker for that. The other thing, is that despite this game having what seems to be a pretty straightforward crafting system, I have no idea what I'm crafting and how much of each material the thing I am crafting takes. It says, "200% more ore" but doesn't tell me exactly how much of what. Perhaps I've missed something early on in the game. Other than that, I can gladly say that this is a great game. There are moments when the story, the action, and the music all come together to a near final fantasy level moment. Since then, I now have Deadly Sin and Deadly Sin 2. I've also got my eye on Echoes of Aetheria. One last thing, I believe I picked this game by either Humble Bundle or one of the bundle sites. If it were not for that, I never would have heard of it. I am glad I came across this gem!

Posted: March 1, 2016
												Skyborn is probably the best RPGMaker game in the market, it is a fun RPG with lovely visuals and a great story that will keep you motivated until the end.Pros:  Lovely textures and character drawings.  Well made Steampunk world with an interesting society.  Unforgettable cast of characters.  Nice, fitting soundtrack.  A great story that makes the game more enjoyable.Cons:  The game is short, after 8.5 hrs I've finished the main story. This has a good side, you barely have to do any grinding so all your time in the game will be enjoyable.  Lack of secondary quests, the game is made towards the main story, I only found 2 secondary quests along the way.  The game resolution is locked to 640x480 so I had to play the whole thing on a small window on my 1080p monitor. (You can play it on fullscreen mode but if your monitor is 16:9 it will look stretched)Overall I really enjoyed my experience with Skyborn and would definitely recommend it, specially if you can get it on sale.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												After reading the synopsis for this game, I was unsure of what to expect. The story sounded dull, but I was looking for a new RPG to play, so I gave Skyborn a chance. In the end, I am very glad I made that decision.I was enthralled by the lovable characters, the gorgeous environments, and a surprisingly endearing story. Skyborn also utilizes a targeting system called “Threat Levels”, which results in very satisfying battles.Although the game can be completed in a short amount of time, in my opinion, it is worth the full price.  If you are looking for an excellent turn-based RPG to play, I highly recommend this game.

Posted: March 18, 2016
												I just finished this game, the save data says it took me around 7 hours, but it's probably less if you don't try to get everything and kill everything like I do. Posted: March 19, 2016
												Skyborn........ where to begin. I completed this rpg in about 15 hours and I must say it was well worth it. But as usual, I like to give my likes and dislikes with every review so let's begin.Likes:1. Compelling story, truly an innocative piece. The whole story surrounding skyborn is enthralling and worth discovery the aspects of what, how and when did they came to be.2. Characters are well thought out and utterly enjoying, had a few laughs and lead protanganist stoood out quite clearly among the others, however I must say all contributed to making the game enjoyable.3. Battle system is damn good for an RPG such as this, developers got this down. Skills were on point for each character and it was nice that they thought of an upgrade system as well.4. Augmenting system was verry good, love that aspect. did not use much of the actual making thing part of the game, but that was also well done.5. Grapppphics, the graphics of the game is astounding, this is the first 2D..I think, rpg with such beautiful graphics I was amazed. Cleaan and not overbearing.Seee basicallly, a recommended game from all of these points. But on to dislikes.1. Sometimes there was some kinda lag or drag...like a fps thing. I am rather confused why this happens since it requires limited specs to run.2. Difficulty, yes I played it on hard, so why the hell am I complaining if I got my♥♥♥♥♥handed to me. Welll....I defeated MOST of the bosses on hard, but the thing is once you defeat a monster, they dont respawn so you basically have a limited level cap from what exp points you gather. So the question is, how on earth I am suppose to beat something when you go from 1 to 1000 in the gap between one battle to the next. NUH MEK NO SENSE TO ME. But I digress I changed the difficulty in 4 instances because of this.3. Why no respawn of monsters,if you lack the necessary level to win then it would make sense to level up. Thats rpg, I dont like turing down the difficulty just to progress in the story, and YES I TRIED, and it impossibru. 4. What elsse.... could use just a little more sidequest, think it was only 2. Could have improvise more and still not compromise the quality of the game.Overall pretty good, I recommended...ooh wait yes.5. The price of this game is not worth 14.99 it is marketed for. Should have been priced waaay lower. Yes it is well planned and so, but the value does not equate the experience. But I bought it for maybe $6.99 while on sale.. and I think that is more deserving. But then again, I from Jamaiaca, wher my dollar is quite devalued and so it is hard to fork out soo much money for an rpg as this. But then maybe mi cheap, who knows...hhappy playing folks.

Posted: April 5
												I enjoyed Skyborn. I played it through with all the side quests completed and side areas explored, played the ending through twice to get an additional achievement, which adds about two hours to my playtime. I also meandered around a little, messing about with equipment and augments. I'm not particularly skilled at games, so I expect someone more experienced would take a shorter amount of time to run through it.I'm mostly interested in story and characters, so it was interesting to be caught up in a revolution, and I adored the main cast of characters. The game doesn't really have romance, although it was teased throughout, so the ending wasn't quite satisfying for me, and it opened up a fascinating possible plot thread that didn't really get addressed. Story-wise though, it was a good ending, with the main plot being wrapped up in a satisfying way.It's a fun game, though I would recommend getting it on sale.

Posted: December 29, 2015
"Among all the RPG Maker titles on Steam, Skyborn is one of the most solid entries for the genre."The premise is simple; Claret Spencer, a genius mechanic and protagonist of the story, gets herself involved in a conflict between the Skyborn, a Dragon race who oppress the rest of the population, specially those who are hybrids, and a rebel group led by a mysterious individual that seek to free these citizens from the Skyborn's hands.The game features likeable, yet small, cast of characters, which are pretty well developed, considering the rather short length of the game. There are several "tiers" of equipment available during the course of the story, which can be enhanced with extra attack, hp, element resistances, and other bonuses. Grinding for a few levels might be necessary, but having the right equipment and upgrades is more than good enough (specially for the arena bosses, some of which are pretty tough without the right resistances).Overall, Skyborn is a fun game with a engaging story and more than decent characterization. Recommended for those who enjoy classic RPG's.

Posted: December 10, 2016
												If you like old school turn based RPGs you'll like this game. It has a nice compact story with reasonable twists and surprises. Combat is solid, multiple levels of difficulty, enemies don't respawn so there's no grinding nor any need to grind. Use your money, equipment, and augments wisely and you'll be able to overcome any challenges in the game.

Product received for free
												RPGmaker truly comes into its own in this game. It's got a well thought out combat system, an interesting story, and a very interesting world design with pixel art to match.

Posted: December 25, 2015
												8/10 Ladies and Gentlemen, Skyborn. Truly a hidden gem. Got it for free. No regrets, totally worth every dollar if you paid for it.[Menu/Video Settings/Audio]+ Simple save/load system with more than sufficient save slots if you want to try different team builds.+ Easy customisable audio (BGM, BGS, SFX)+ Amazing soundtrack (I especially like the Main Menu one)+ Text speed configuration (Saves you so much pain if you dislike slow text)+ Minor details such as window skin colour- Lack of resolution configuration, video quality settings (Well, okay, since it's kinda themed like GBA games)- No controller support (Would've loved it, for even greater feel of old style console games)- Really low frames that hurt when you run on a monitor with high res + refresh rate + large screen)[Gameplay]+ Great character development, backstories introduced slowly at appropriate times+ Final Fantasy styled combat system, giving a very strategic, engaging feel (Can't always rely on dumb luck)+ Overall mostly a good plot, although I feel kinda like there was much more to expect after the ending+ Good degree of flexibility to customise your combat style with 2 class changes per character (except last character)- Combat can get kinda repetitive at some points where the monster encounter density is too high- Replayability is not so much, unless you just want to try out new classes or finish the side questsJust a good game. If it's on sale for less than 10, just buy it already.

Posted: December 18, 2016
												This a must play game for anyone who likes Zalda/link games back from the NES era (Gameplay was very retro RPG). Posted: July 3, 2015
												This game was a very satisfying and quickly immersive new-age RPG. It had a feeling reminiscent of FF6 and Chrono Trigger for me, which was a big plus given my love of those games. The combat was quite addicting, and the different class choices, in addition to gear customization up the wazoo, made character progression very fulfilling. It is a fairly short game (I did 95% of everything, and I clocked a little under 20 hrs in my playthrough), but I loved every minute of it. The only complaint I might make is the ending felt somewhat abrupt, and I definitey ended up feeling like I wanted more.

Posted: July 2, 2015
												Skyborn is a short RPGMaker-made game that's very good looking (in the japanese anime classical style) and has great music.  It exposes interracial and social classes conflicts in a steampunk-fantasy sort of environment. The story is good but the arcs of the characters' stories are not very complicated and there are no important choices to make or crossroads where several endings can develop.Fights are not at every corner of an alley because you can visually choose (most of the times) if you fight enemies or you just ignore them. The story/fighting ratio is well balanced, but while some generic enemies are a piece of cake some bosses are a pain in the mouse's left button. By the way, while some enemies' design goes according to the world presented, some others seem to have been taken out of other very different projects.Gameplay is easy either with a keyboard or with the mouse, but the UI both in the character menus and in battle is a little bit of a mess and if you pause the game for a long time you will have to re-learn almost everything. Fights are repetitive and turn-based and the special effects are not outstanding but acceptable. You can upgrade your characters' classes and abbilities but even then some of they are left behind while others grow.I recommend Skyborn if you like classical J-turn-based-RPGs and you are not too exigent.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												While this game harkens back to what is good about console RPGs...character leveling; weapon mods; mathematics based combat; boss monsters...it barely builds up enough steam before the game ends. However, character leveling is missing skill customization and is automatic tacked on attribute points; weapon mods are very simple and is easy to get to the higher level wpns; boss monsters really aren't that powerful or add much story (and no good item drops) to the arena they appear.I've logged 15 hrs which is very short compared to the weeks I spent playing things like FF. But then this game was purchased for $4.

Posted: December 10, 2015
												A story of rebellion against an unjust dictator(s), of human integrity, and of magic vs technology.  There's also a random chick who threatens, emptily, to eat you but never tries.  Unless you let her (but for real, why was she in the game)!  You play as Claret, a mechanic in the upper level of human society who repairs airships and makes the occasional automaton who can beep.  She somehow understands perfectly because reasons.  In her life is her brother and some random dude.  Her brother ends up being an awful guy (for reasons you'll learn five minutes in), but only for the first 10 minutes.  After wards, he changes into a damsel in distress and then we forget he exists.  If you don't have character art/portraits, then no one cares about you.  Welcome to video games.  The game play is typical old school RPG affair: you go to various lands; a desert, a volcano (that has surprising soothing music), a forest, ruins, and a multi-layered, caste style city.  You meet various people from all background, five of which are usable in combat, and then save the world.  Combat is a bit different than many games.  For the first half it's, arguably, optional.  You can find shining dots across the map and use that to level-up which give more exp than the actual monsters (only early on).  They're pretty easy to see to don't worry about missing any, besides, there's always the actual combat system to level up on.  Once you get all five characters, the dots effectiveness diminishes and killing monsters starts to be rewarding.  Fortunately, the battles can be fun.  Each character has a set of skills they learn, and that depend on their role in your party and the class you choose from.  At several points in the game, you have the option (meaning it's also optional) to upgrade character classes and learn new skills and passively upgrade stats.  Here's the kicker, though.  All of the skills are useful through out all of the game.  We've all played games where the earliest skills becomes obsolete about 10 minutes after learning it but Skyborn isn't one of those games.  That level 1 skill is still useful throughout the entire game or, at the very least, becomes a bridge to the more powerful, expensive, skills learned later in the game.  This is especially true for the non-magical characters who use energy (EN) to attack.  These characters gain EN when using basic attacks, or 0 EN skills, and release the EN when using the more powerful skills.  Buff/debuffs are one or two of a kind and are useful at all portions.  There is also a threat system that works similar to MMORPGS where, whoever has the most threat, gets punched in the face.  There is a bar that says who has what and is only relevant to enemy parties.  You can still attack whoever.  You also have the option to play each character in a variety of ways.  Do you want your mage to do damage with in-hands or with their spells?  Do you one character to be the buff/debuff character or the straight DPS?  Which character do you want to the tank?  Even the gear add to this.  Late game, there are multiple options for equipment for each character.  Some raise INT to do more damage with skills, some raise STR to do more with in-hands.  There are some limitations but there are freedoms not seen often in Skyborn.  *Keep in mind, I was playing on easy mode.  Apparently, hard has more set restrictions.Characters are not on-screen in combat but the enemy sprites are.  Sadly, there is no animation but animation is hard and expensive for a small 2-3 people company.  Spell effects do exist and most are 32-bit pretty so there's something to look at while you shoot a “totally not a manticore” in the face.  There are no random battles and each enemy cluster is visible on the screen and only enters combat when it touches you.  The characters all have a definite personality and the developers did of a good job of trying to get you to emphasize with them.  There's the strong, independent female lead, the rich guy who actually just wants to be the hero, the good natured girl-beast who has been treated like an outcast, the sick of being pushed around mage, and the always questioning “superior race”.  When one character can no longer do a certain “thing” at the end of game, you feel bad.  When you find about the final fate of those captives, you're shocked and disgusted.  I was torn during the middle of the game when faced with the moral dilemma.  Alas, this is a liner game so the moral dilemma didn't fall into my hands but was played out as it did.  The game boosts an original soundtrack that is pretty good.  Nothing spectacular but nothing ruins the mood.  It's all very relaxing and worth listening to once or twice.  I'd get into specifics but I'm a bad musician and everyone has their own tastes so here's some streamable links so you can decide on your own:Spotify Web Player[open.spotify.com]iTunes[itunes.apple.com]Art Work is pretty.  I'm not familiar with RPGMaker so I can't say how much of it has been over saturated in it's games.  Typical retro style; look at the screenshots.  Overall, Skyborn was a fun experience and, since the game is often on sale, is worth the money spent and time “wasted”.  I got 16 hours out of it and I've seen the game sell for a few bucks USD and it's worth it on sale.

Posted: January 25
												I wanted to try an RPG style game for the first time, and this caught my eye as it has a female protagonist (a non-Mary Sue one at that!) I was a little skeptical at first, but the gorgeous art and soundtrack quickly won me over. There is no character in this game that is not at least understandable. The protagonists are likeable and relateable, and there were parts of the ending that I honestly didn't see coming. Fairly easy to beat, but really hard to get 100% completion, so good replay value. The humor is spot on, as is the pathos. All in all, a great introduction to the genre for me. Five stars easy.

When one character can no longer do a certain “thing” at the end of game, you feel bad.  When you find about the final fate of those captives, you're shocked and disgusted.  I was torn during the middle of the game when faced with the moral dilemma.  Alas, this is a liner game so the moral dilemma didn't fall into my hands but was played out as it did.  The game boosts an original soundtrack that is pretty good.  Nothing spectacular but nothing ruins the mood.  It's all very relaxing and worth listening to once or twice.  I'd get into specifics but I'm a bad musician and everyone has their own tastes so here's some streamable links so you can decide on your own:Spotify Web Player[open.spotify.com]iTunes[itunes.apple.com]Art Work is pretty.  I'm not familiar with RPGMaker so I can't say how much of it has been over saturated in it's games.  Typical retro style; look at the screenshots.  Overall, Skyborn was a fun experience and, since the game is often on sale, is worth the money spent and time “wasted”.  I got 16 hours out of it and I've seen the game sell for a few bucks USD and it's worth it on sale.

Posted: April 18
												Solid, short, fun. It's not exceptional, the combat isn't spectacular, and sometimes it can be a little mazelike. That being said, the score is ok, the graphics and portraits are really good, and the characters are great. The only real problem I have with Skyborn is that it feels almost cut-off. Like the game finishes two-thirds of the way through and doesn't have the time to build up to the climax and denouement. Instead everything finishes all at once very rapidly and feels somewhat unsatisfying.

Posted: October 6, 2015
												Skyborn is a thoughtful and modernly designed RPG, in that it allows for those of us who just no longer have the time or interest to devote to typical RPG trappings such as battle grinding and complex inventory management.It reminds me of Final Fantasy, there's not much difference between the two of them.If you like RPG type games, this one's a must for you!08/10
